title: pm brexit boundaries no deal vote james forsyth
story: The symbolic defeat that MPs inflicted on her Brexit plan on Thursday night has signicantly weakened her negotiating position.The EU doesn’t want to make signicant changes to the backstop. It repeats endlessly that the withdrawal agreement is closed and that it isn’t going to reopen it.When the Brady amendment passed the House of Commons, saying Parliament would accept the dealthe backstop was replaced, the EU responded by saying they didn’t think this Parliament majority was “stable”.Thursday night’s vote helps them make that argument.As one No source laments: “We don’t want to give the Europeans a chance not to engage with us.”I understand that when the Brexit Secretary, Steve Barclay, dined in Brussels this week Sabine Weyand — the EU’s deputy negotiator — spent her time telling him that a customs union was the only major change available to the backstop.The EU think that Corbyn’s support for it means that a customs union could pass Parliament. I am told Barclay attempted to disabuse them of this idea.Mrs May can’t entirely escape blame for this week’s fiasco.No should have made sure that its own MPs were happy with the wording before publishing the motion.“She’s like a football team that can’t string two wins together,” complains one minister.But the Tory Brexit ultras should have paid more heed to the real-world consequences of their actions.Another effect of Thursday night’s defeat for the Government is that it increases the chances of the Cooper amendment passing on February .This would compel the Government to seek an extension to Article Mrs May hasn’t won Parliament’s support for an exit deal by March .One Cabinet minister, with close links to several of the ministers who might quit to ensure this amendment goes through, tells me it is now “much more likely” to pass.This Secretary of State complains that the Government’s defeat “makes it harder to make the argument that we should hold our nerve” as “the best evidence for holding your nerve was that the outcome would be the same as when the Brady amendment went through”.Another minister warns: “If she doesn’t come back with something cooking by the th, there’ll be trouble.”I understand those around Mrs May know they need to have shown progress by the th.One insider tells me: “If the Government doesn’t want Parliament to take control, they need to have a plan.They can’t just sit there for two weeks.”Other Cabinet ministers aren’t so sure Cooper will pass.One tells me: “I don’t think the ministers will resign, andthey don’t resign, then it doesn’t pass.”If Cooper does go through, politics will enter into an even more unpredictable phase. One May Cabinet ally is predicting a general electionthis happens.But it is hard to see how a general election could end in anything other than disaster for the Tories in these circumstances.If Mrs May is forced to ask the EU for an extension but with no Parliamentary agreement in sight, the EU is more likely to offer a long extension than a short one.I understand the view in several EU capitals is that the longer the extension, the more likely it is that the political dynamics in the UK will change.But a long extension would prolong this damaging, political uncertainty.This Government, and this Parliament’s, job is to get Brexit done. Time is running short. Both Parliament and the Government need to get their act together.But it may well be because the NHS – traditionally Labour’s strongest suit – is not the most important issue in politics right now.But that number is down to  per cent this winter, according to the pollster Ipsos Mori.The question now is whether the Tory decision to spend an extra £billion a year on the health service by  leads to a decline in public concern.But in January AE departments recorded their worst waiting times since the figures started being collected in .Matt Hancock, the new Health Secretary, is setting up a new NHS-X unit to try to bring the health service into the digital era, which would help the NHS to better use its resources.There are many things the Tories have to do to win the next election – not least, deliver Brexit – but they must also reassure voters on the NHS.Butthey can be ed they should be subject to the full force of the law.Justice must be done and must be seen to be done.Churchill wouldn’t have been Prime Minister but for the Labour Party’s willingness to serve in a government led by him.When it came to the crucial decision to fight on in , Clement Attlee and Arthur Greenwood, two Labour members of the War Cabinet, were more solid than some of Churchill’s Tory colleagues.But Attlee and Greenwood came from a very dferent Labour tradition to McDonnell: They weren’t Marxists or Trotskyists.There are some Labour MPs who are just not prepared to try to put into power people who are so outside the traditional bounds of the party.One minister likens the coming Tory leadership race to the  Grand National, when a crowded field led to a pile-up at the rd fence and the victory of the - outsider Foinavon.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: the sun says brexit compromise jeremy corbyn
story: The EU must compromise too.They know they can make firmer legally-binding promises on the hated Irish backstop. Time to offer them up.Brexiteers must then hold their noses and vote for Theresa May’s deal. All other roads lead to catastrophe.They won’t get the backstop removed. We don’t believe they’ll get a No Deal exit either, and eventhey did the short-term chaos would kill their party.Instead Parliament would postpone Brexit, possibly finishing the Tories for a generation. This current purgatory would go on for months longer — maybe long enough for Remainers to reverse the referendum result.The Government would have failed in its only mission. It would instead have undermined our democracy and ensured bitter isions that would never heal.The one person unable to compromise, oddly, is the Prime Minister. Because what Brussels, Labour and Tory Remainers glibly ask of her, a permanent customs union, ALSO wrecks her party and destroys Brexit’s economic case.It was folly to expect the Tory ERG group to vote to “take No Deal off the table” on Thursday night. Logic was on their side, at least.But they need to think hard now how they will feel on March Brexit is put off and they are blamed. If they have opened the door to a toxic, anti-Semitic, anti-Western Labour rabble so crazed by ideology they cannot even allow Winston Churchill’s historic defeat of Nazism to trump his other failings.A party committed to massive tax rises, maybe even a  per cent windfall levy on anyone’s “wealth”. A party led by pension-age Marxist revolutionaries friendly to Putin, Hamas, the IRA and hard-left dictators but hard on private enterprise, job-creation and free speech.We sincerely hope Labour moderates stop dithering and resign to undermine Corbyn and McDonnell. We marvel that so many can still stomach these sinister men poised to do unimaginable harm.But eventhey can’t grasp that, Tory Brexiteers can. And we say this to them:Wake up. Look how close you now are to bringing this calamity about.WILL the Government squander the biggest potential shale gas discovery in our history It is believed there is enough under the East Midlands alone to power Britain cheaply for  years.Yet the Tories are suffocating this new industry at birth by persisting with an absurdly low limit on the level of tremor allowable when drilling. title: bbc parasite free press shamima begum
story: With its enormous resources of £billion of your money every year, you might think the BBC itself unearthed this news.But it was not the Beeb that did the heavy lting — it was a newspaper. And it was an old-school print journalist, the brilliant Anthony Loyd of The Times, who found Begum in a Syrian refugee camp containing almost , people.Loyd’s interview with her is a gripping insight into the twisted mind of a British youngster who ran off to join IS’s murderous caliphate. And the BBC had bugger all to do with it.While BBC staffers were sipping their skinny lattes and nibbling almond croissants in Broadcasting House, a journalist from The Times got his scoop the hard way, tramping into a chaotic refugee camp in one of the most dangerous parts of the world.Why does this matter  Because this country has one of the most vibrant newspaper industries on the planet.And the bloated, over-funded BBC is KILLING it.The Cairncross Review, a Government report into the future of UK journalism, revealed this week how tax-dodging tech giants Facebook and Google, together with the publicly-funded BBC are annihilating our free Press.They have already destroyed what was once affectionately known as “the local rag”.Over the past seven years, hundreds of local papers have shut down and thousands of regional journalists have lost their jobs. , journalists worked on local newspapers in  — now it is just ,. And it is your money that bankrolls the BBC.At a time when the BBC is contem­plating ditching free TV licences for the over-s, the debate we should REALLY be having is about how much of your money we should be chucking at Auntie.We have a great newspaper industry and it is worth preserving.Because it wasn’t the BBC that broke the story of MPs fiddling their expenses — it was a newspaper . And it wasn’t the BBC that broke the story about charity Age UK receiving £million from an energy company to flog gas and electricity to pensioners — it was a newspaper .It wasn’t the BBC that dared to publish the names of the killers of Stephen Lawrence — it was a newspaper .And what was the most-read story on the BBC last year  Strictly minx Katya Jones snogging Seann Walsh  — a Sun on Sunday exclusive.The BBC, like Facebook and Google, is a parasite that lives off the flesh of real news-gatherers.What makes the BBC dferent from the tax-dodging tech giants is that we love it. And you can’t grow up in this country and not have a deep and abiding affection for the BBC.I have endless happy memories of the BBC — from Match Of The Day to Top Of The Pops, from David Attenborough documentaries to The Likely Lads, from Fawlty Towers to the Hairy Cornflake.But the BBC has got far too big, far too bloated and far too wealthy.Lord Reith, the visionary behind it, wanted our state broadcaster to “inform, educate and entertain”. Lord Reith never dreamed of a state broadcaster that was all-powerful.The BBC gets far too much of your money and spends it far too easily. Why does the BBC need to be over every nook and cranny of the internet To the generation growing up on Netflix and YouTube with an entire universe on their smartphones, the BBC pocketing more than £ a year from everyone with a TV set is absurd.The BBC has got too big for its publicly-funded boots.That’s what we should be talking about — not the merits of free TV licences for granny and grandad!The Cairncross Review told how the BBC’s expansionist online empire has come very close to destroying the local newspaper industry.Are we really going to keep giving the BBC £billion every year so it can do the same to the national newspaper industry In the same week as the Cairncross Review came out, Bruce Sharma, , fought off thieves armed with a hammer and a machete with just his rolled-up copy of The Sun.Bruce was reading The Sun in Ram Stores in Long Eaton, Derbys, when the hooded pair burst in demanding money. “Instinct took over and I tried to whack them with the paper,” says Bruce.You can’t do that with a TV licence.GORDON Banks lit up my childhood.For my generation – a wide-eyed kid on that magical summer’s day in  – those World Cup winners will always feel like family.Gordon never got a knighthood. But he did get a pat on the head for his impossible save from Pele in .My favourite Banks save was the one he made when a dog ran on the pitch at Leicester in .The dog is moving at some speed. But Banks collects him with his left hand under the mutt’s chest and his right hand on the dog’s butt – a perfect catch.Rest in peace, Gordon. Always England’s No.LABOUR’S John McDonnell, who has spent his political career licking the boots of the IRA, describes Winston Churchill as a “villain”.Not the same Churchill who inspired this country when we stood alone against Nazi Germany’s subjugation of Europe  Yes, that’s the chap.IRA groupie McDonnell reckons the greatest Englishman in history was a villain because Winnie sent troops to Wales during a miners’ strike in .History tells us that Churchill was reluctant to involve troops in a miners’ strike.But why bother with the facts The likes of John McDonnell despise this country, our heroes, our history and believe the British are always the wicked ones.Even when fighting for our lives against Hitler!GAVIN “Mad Dog” Williamson, our gung-ho Defence Secretary, says excitedly that the RAF will get “swarm squadrons” of drones to confuse enemy defences.Mad Dog is full of ideas about how the UK is ready to use “hard power” against Russia and China.Williamson’s moronic sabre-rattling disturbs real soldiers.“We don’t want a war in the South China Sea,” says Admiral Lord West of Spithead, a former head of the Royal Navy, who counsels against “talking wildly and loosely” about fighting China.Now Williamson’s macho posturing is causing our country harm.China’s Deputy Prime Minister, Hu Chunhua, was due to hold trade talks with Chancellor Philip Hammond but cancelled the meeting because our Mad Dog Defence Secretary had been ranting about China’s military ambitions.The UK does not want to fight a war with China and Russia, Mad Dog. We want to TRADE with them.Memo to Mrs May – your Defence Secretary is a national embarrassment.“I have a little wine with meals, and a Guinness or a beer or two, but otherwise no. Mind you,I meet you in a bar and you say, ‘Do you want a drink ’, I wouldn’t turn you down.This must seem like a squeaky-clean existence to Keith.The rest of us would call it “still drinking”.CONGRATULATIONS to Myleene Klass, fabulously pregnant at  and looking forward to giving a baby sibling to her daughters Ava, , and Hero, seven.Myleene has had her ups and downs – but then haven’t we all These include a failed first marriage and a period when wine o’clock was starting before noon.Now she has found real and lasting happiness with PR Simon Motson.We all remember Myleene showering under that waterfall in the jungle but what she doesn’t get enough credit for is becoming the best DJ on radio.With her work on Smooth and Classic FM, nobody plays such a wide range of banging tunes.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: burnt toast more toxic traffic fumes
story: Researchers at the University of Texas at Austin found burnt toast was especially harmful and the safest way was to “go for gold” – allowing the bread to turn a light gold colour.The team of experts built a mock-up of a three-bed house and equipped it with monitors to assess how everyday activities impacted on air quality.Roasting and frying can also prove to be toxic, the research found.But researcher Marina Vance said the biggest shock was discovering just what the impact of toasters was.It was found they sent toxic particles into the air the moment they are switched on, The Times has reported.Vance told the American Association for the Advancement of Science: “When you make toast, the heating element starts warming up the debris and gunk in the toaster which includes oils.”Revealing the early results of the research the assistant professor added: “Add to that the bread itself - it’s going to emit a range of things.“We found ethanol, a by-product of yeast.“If there’s tiny pieces of bread touching the heating element you can see the smoke, maybe from crumbs at the bottom of the toaster - they will all make a lot of particles.“It led to what would be considered ‘very unhealthy’ air pollution levelscompared to outdoor air quality standards.”Other pollutants included cleaning agents, especially household sprays, and air-puriers which give off scents when plugged in to a socket.Scented candles and wood-burning stoves were also found to be powerful polluters.Other research recently published in the academic journal Atmosphere measured just how bad some of the pollutants were.The World Health Organisationrecommends air should contain no more than  micrograms of fine particulates.US experts advise ditching furnishings with PBDEs and BBP, which are linked to cancer and obesity.The research found that when bread was turned golden brown particle concentrations in the surrounding air surge to between  and  micrograms per cubic metre.When toast was allowed to turn dark brown, then the particle levels soared to ,-, micrograms per cubic metre, up to more than  times the WHO limit.The Marylebone Road in central London, which has one of highest levels of pollution in the country, was double the limit of  micrograms on  occasions in , according to figures from Kings College London.Jonathan Grigg, a professor who chairs a committee which is currently investigating indoor air pollution in the UK, said: “This research could be a wake-up call to the risks posed by toasting and toasters.”" data-credit"" data-sizes"auto" data-img"https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   SD-TOAST-GRAPHIC-COMPOSITE.jpg stripallw" src"data:image svg+xml,%Csvg xmlnshttp:www.w.org  svg viewBox  . %E%C svg%E"

title: family dream holiday cuba green swimming pool poo stained toilets
story: Mother Gayle Evans said she broke down in tears as she witnessed the family’s first trip away together ruined.The troop were there to celebrate Gayle’s th birthday, and with children growing fast, she said it might be one of the last chances to get them all together.But what they found at the Brisas del Caribe hotel was a world away from the hotels glossy brochure images.She told the Birmingham Mail: We spent weeks dreaming about it, of lying on the gorgeous beach and paddling in the sea, splashing in the pools, sipping cocktails in the piano bar - we thought it was going to be wonderful.“I just burst into tears. It was awful. I could not believe how bad it was.The trip included Gayle, husband Steve, daughters Ayla, , and Gabby, , and son Jaz,  and his girlfriend Laura, .Gayle described the hotel as being “in a state of decay”, complete with exposed electronics and obviously used towels in the rooms.There was litter everywhere, the pools had green scum on the surface and there was broken furniture and beach beds.To add insult to injury, nearly the whole family were laid out with a stomach bug during the trip.The family submitted a catalogue of complaints to their tour rep on the first day of their stay and asked for a move to another hotel - but were advised there was nowhere that was better quality than the one they were in.The holiday company the family had booked through, The Holiday Place, responded to the complaints to offer a meagre £ voucher each off any future break with the company.The Holiday Place told the Birmingham Mail: Due to GDPRwe cannot discuss this case with you however and we have been in contact with the client to handle the matter directly.The hotel has an average rating of .  on TripAdvisor.The Sun Online have contacted the hotel for comment.Despite the poor accommodation, Gayle said the family enjoyed the surrounding stunning beaches of Varader.

title: iran cruise missile submarine targets america israel
story: The battle sub - named Fateh- was launched by hardline President Hassan Rouhani in the port of Bandar Abbas and can hit targets , miles away.From this moment, the Fateh Submarine joins Irans naval force with my order, Rouhani said in a ceremony broadcast live on the state-run English-language Press TV.Reporters claimed the Fateh weighs  tonnes and enjoys state-of-the-art weaponry, including torpedoes, naval mines and cruise missiles that could be launched from a submerged position.President Donald Trump pulled out of a  nuclear agreement between Iran and six powers last May and reimposed sanctions on Tehran.He said the deal was flawed because it did not include curbs on Irans development of ballistic missiles or its support for proxies in Syria, Yemen, Lebanon and Iraq.Iran has developed a large domestic arms industry in the face of international pressure and embargoes that have barred it from importing many weapons.Our defence power is solely defensive...Our enemys pressure and sanctions imposed on Iran have instigated our progress, Rouhani said in the southern port city of Bandar Abbas.Last year, Irans navy launched a domestically-built destroyer, which state media said has radar-evading stealth properties.Iran says it has missiles with the range of up to , miles, which puts old enemy Israel and US military bases in the region within reach.The European signatories of Irans nuclear deal, despite remaining committed to the pact, have stepped up criticism of Irans ballistic missiles program.Last week, US Vice-President Mike Pence demanded EU allies withdraw from the Iran nuclear deal which had aimed to stop the Middle Eastern country developing nukes.Trumps second-in-command also accused its European partners of trying to break US sanctions against Tehran which have been slapped down on the Islamic Republic to force it to give up their weapons programme.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: fun fair ride closed people trapped manchester
story: Thrill-seekers were stuck in their seats on the Air Max ride at the fair in Oldham because of an electrical fault, according to reports.The ride swings passengers in  degree loops at  metres up in the air at speeds of up to kph.Crews from Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service were called by a member of the public.Nobody was hurt during the incident on Sunday, according to Manchester Evening News.Bosses at the Blackpool Comes to Oldham fair in Greater Manchester said bars on the seats didnt unlock due to the fault.The ride was closed as a precaution.Were you on the Air Max ride  Call the newsdesk on    or email tips@the-sunThe Air Max ride is due to be be back up and running by Monday once safety tests have been carried out, the fairs site manager Jake Dekoning said.Mr Dekoning said: The ride stopped as it normally does.Due to an electrical fault, the bars didnt unlock straight away.Weve had to fix the fault and it took us around  to  minutes to get the bars open and get everyone off.In that time, a member of the public called the fire brigade. We closed it for the day and will test it in the morning.It should be open as normal tomorrow.Firefighters from Hollins and Chadderton were called to the scene.A health and safety team from Oldham council is understood to have attended.A fire service spokesman said: We were called to reports of people trapped on a ride on Railway Road in Hollinwood.All those affected were released and there were no injuries.Fire crews from Hollins and Chadderton stations attended.The ride will remain closed until further safety tests have been conducted.

title: mh370 co pilot jet ghost plane sleuth claims
story: Aviation writer Christine Negroni believes the doomed jet may have suddenly depressurised during its final deadly flight from Malaysia to China.And she believes the Boeing -s captain - Zaharie Ahmad Shah - may have been on a break at the time leaving Fariq Abdul Hamid at the controls.The author suspects Fariq failed to stop the planes final descent after suffering from hypoxia - when the brain is starved of oxygen.However because he was the only one in the cockpit, Negroni believes he lived longer than the rest of those on board- leaving the plane to fly under its own steam.The author of The Crash Detectives: Investigating the Worlds Most Mysterious Air Disasters, told the Daily Star Online: The plane starts heading south. Whatever that time period is, thats the period of time I believe he went unconscious.The oxygen available for the passengers was about  minutes, so the passengers were all dead, theres no chance they were resuscitated, they were dead long before that plane hit the water.Last week, an air crash investigator has said the Malaysian Airline fligh was crashed deliberately in a “murder-suicide” and he could prove it.Canadian aviation expert Larry Vance said he was “certain” either captain Shah or his co-pilot took over the plane in what he said was “criminal event” and “made it disappear forever”.Mystery has surrounded the disappearance of the Malaysia Airlines flight from Kuala Lumpur to Beijing on March ,  when the plane simply vanished with  passengers and crew on board and has not been found.Vance, who previously worked for the Transportation Safety Board of Canada, told CBC News: “It’s not an accident. This was planned and conducted, carried out by one inidual who had control of the aeroplane via his job to have control of the plane.”He claimed that the pilot or co-pilot made the decision “to take it to a remote part of the ocean and make it disappear forever”.Passengers included Chinese calligraphers, a couple on their way home to their young sons after a long-delayed honeymoon and a construction worker who hadnt been home in a year.But at .am on March , , Malaysia Airlines lost contact with MH close to Phuket island in the Strait of Malacca.Before that, Malaysian authorities believe the last words heard from the plane, from either the pilot or co-pilot, was Good night Malaysian three seven zero.Satellite pings from the aircraft suggest it continued flying for around seven hours when the fuel would have run out.Experts have calculated the most likely crash site around , miles west of Perth, Australia.But a huge search of the seabed failed to find any wreckage - and there are a number of alternative theories as to its fate.Vance spent  months doing research for his book MH Mystery Solved, but he was not part of the official investigation by the Australian Transport Safety Bureau.Vance’s theory has not been accepted by everyone.Former head of the Australian Transport Safety Bureau Martin Dolan said on  Minutes: “The evidence is not yet sufficient to draw as firm a conclusion as you appear to have done.”He said there were two possible theories - that someone was in control of the plane or not - and that “there’s evidence that supports both of those theories”.Dolan added: The evidence is not yet sufficient to draw as firm a conclusion as you appear to have done.”

title: eu lorries security checks no deal brexit avoid jams hmrc customs
story: HMRC will this week declare a six month “standstill” in an admission that Border Force is nowhere near ready to cope with the extra administration.They have already waived the need for goods declarations at U.K. ports because of fears of massive jams.The Sun last week revealed the Home Office wanted hauliers to fill out -point safety and security forms in the event of No Deal. Truckers would be fined £,they failed to comply.Currently the paperwork has to be completed by anyone bringing goods in from outside the EU.A source claimed: “HMRC has written to both the Home Office and the Treasury to say it has to allow a ‘phasing in’ period. They’re worried that any extra red tape could disrupt the flow of goods into the country.”Home Office insiders are desperate to insist they won’t be putting Britain at risk and have other intelligence to protect the border.But the move will enrage MPs and campaigners who claim HMRC has taken far too long to prepare Britain for A No Deal.HMRC chief John Thompson last year warned it could take two more years to have a fully ing IT system in place to cope with the extra number of checks required for a No Deal Brexit.He said officials would face a trade off between collecting revenue minimising disruption at the border or security. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: labour historic split 100 mps ed miliband yvettte cooper face being ousted
story: Several party moderates are expected to announce theyre quitting as soon as TODAY.The group are furious at Jeremy Corbyn’s failure to get a grip on the anti-Semitism crisis or publicly campaign for a second referendum.And they fear they will fall victim to a massive purge by new left-wing activists who have flooded the party.Leading MPs including Ed Miliband and Yvette Cooper are feared to be among those at risk of deselection, The Daily Mail reported.In total  Labour MPs could face local bids to boot them out – and around a quarter are expected to lose.It comes amid reports that former Labour leadership contender Chuka Umunna is preparing to lead a group to split from the party today.Roughly half a dozen MPs are holding a press conference this morning which could be the moment of truth.One of the potential splitters has reportedly told colleagues thatthey walk away they want to “burn the house down” on their way out.Its not known whether they are planning to set up a new centrist party, or to sit as independents.The split will revive memories of the s Social Democratic Party, which was set up by a group of Labour rebels fed up with left-wing leader Michael Foot.The SDP briefly came close to winning a General Election, before fizzling out and merging with the Liberals to form the modern-day Lib Dems.Rumours of a Labour breakaway have swirled ever since Jeremy Corbyn became the party leader in .But ramped-up talk of deselection could have sped up the process.Moves to deselect MPs do not usually happen until shortly before a general election, next due in .But Labour’s general secretary Jennie Formby has already begun talks on setting the timetable – raising fears a purge is looming.John McDonnell – Corbyn’s closest ally – yesterday warned Labour MPs not to quit.He told the BBC’s Andrew Marr Show: It would be like the s. My constituency in Hayes and Harlington, we had a Labour MP join the SDP and we lost the seat to the Conservatives.“And it basically installed Mrs Thatcher in power for that decade.”

title: bet365 gives losing customers cash to to keep gambling
story: Bet is said to be giving losing punters weekly s of up to  per cent - allowing them to carry on playing after huge losses.Customers who hit the net loss threshold can be turned into VIP users and are even given incentives like the chance to win FA Cup final tickets, it is alleged.Once considered VIPs, punters are assigned their own dedicated advisors who treat them like celebrities, the Daily Mail claims.Bet staff claim the tactic is incentivising people to bet, according to the newspapers under-cover investigation.One employee told the publications investigators: If they’ve lost, say, £, in that week, then we’ll give them a weekly rebate, normally on a Tuesday, and we’ll give them maybe  per cent of that back.The rebates are all part of the brands strategy to reward loyalty.Though Bet users are warned of gambling addiction, the minimum time spent on the site could be as high as eight hours a day.Junior staff are given free rein to give out £ cash bonuses and free spins to any punter that rings the firms customer service line.A spokesman for Bet said: Bet prides itself on providing a safe environment for its customers and goes above and beyond its legal and regulatory requirements to do so, including those set out in the Gambling Commission Licence Conditions and Codes of Practice and we fully refute any allegation or suggestion to the contrary.Bet is at the forefront of ious industry initiatives to further promote and develop, safer gambling practices, including its participation in gambling treatment provider Gamcare’s social responsibility quality trademark scheme, the Safer Gambling Standard.As the LCCP makes clear, operators in the gambling industry are entitled to reward their loyal customers provided they do so in a socially responsible way, as Bet does.Bet takes specic and extensive actions to identy, monitor and assist customers who may be at risk of experiencing gambling-related harm, including by way of the suppressing of marketing material to any such customers and ensuring they are not inappropriately incentivised to intensy their gambling.New UK gambling laws coming into force on April  limit the maximum bet people can place on fixed-odds betting terminals from £ to £.Campaigners have dubbed FOBT machines the “crack cocaine” of gambling. Bets of up to £ can be placed every  seconds.

title: graduate rejected job abusive ex interview headhunted
story: Olivia Bland, , said company boss Craig Dean was like an “abusive ex” and grilled her for two hours during an interview with Web Applications UK in Oldham, Greater Manchester.Since Olivia stopped applying for jobs after her awful experience last month, the English literature and creative writing graduate is now being headhunted by companies offering her work.Olivia, who graduated from Solent University in Southampton, Hampshire, said: “The job hunt has been a strange one.“It seems more like the jobs are hunting me at the moment.”But she insisted she is in no rush to take any of the posts on offer.She added: “I havent been taking very many of the offers too seriously.“Ive only spoken to a handful of people about seriously working for them.“I want to make sure that me and the company are a right fit for each other first, and of course that its a job I would enjoy.“Im trying my best to explore every opportunity and identy whats best for me.”Olivia’s tweets about her interview were retweeted more than , times.Olivia said the tech CEO asked her bizarre questions such as whether or not her parents were still together.She added that he tore apart “line by line” everything she had submitted in the written part of the application process.She said: There is something very off to me about a man who tries his best to intimidate and assert power over a young woman and who continues to push even when he can see that hes making somebody uncomfortable to the point of tears.He also criticised her posture and browsed to see what music she liked on Spoty.She was offered the role of communications assistant, but declined it and detailed why in an email to the company.Olivia wrote: They tear you down, abuse you, take you to breaking point and then they take you out to dinner or buy you a present to apologise and make it seem like theyre the nice guy.This job is supposed to be the present. I dont want it.

title: cabinet minister theresa may wont reopen backstop deal
story: Theresa May vowed to demand the EU reopen the Withdrawal Agreement to make legally binding changes to the hated Irish backstop.But Culture Secretary Jeremy Wright told the BBC’s Andrew Marr Show: “I don’t think it’s the mechanism that matters, it’s the objective.If you get to a place where the potential longevity of the backstop, the potential the backstop lasts forever can be dealt with, that’s what we are all seeking to do.”Tory MP Mark Francois, deputy of the Brexiteer ERG group, said: “If the EU aren’t willing to [re-open the deal], the Withdrawal Agreement won’t go through. We’ll vote it down, it’s that simple.”Mrs May told MPs on January  her plans “will involve reopening the Withdrawal Agreement”.But Tory Brexiteers fear she is going soft. title: irish backstop concessions or no deal
story: If the Government try to pull the wool over the public’s eyes with wishy-washy words from Brussels negotiators, there will be hell to pay.Jeremy Wright yesterday seemed to suggest the Government would be happy with an IOU and a handshake — buthe thinks MPs or voters will be fooled, he’s deluded.We have said that those who believe in Brexit should,the PM secures legitimate changes to the backstop, back her deal to ensure we leave on March .Butthose cast-iron concessions aren’t forthcoming, we must continue preparing for a managed clean break from the EU. We have nothing to fear.This weekend we saw the apocalyptic scenarios dreamed up by Remainers, of grounded planes and massive tailbacks on our roads, are straight-up rubbish.There is plenty of Brexit fatigue but it’s worth remembering that — deal or no deal — we have a bright future ahead.WE have no sympathy for jihadi bride Shamima Begum.She has shown no remorse, offered no apology, and seems to be totally unfazed by Islamic State’s barbarity.Her brass neck is staggering, and it’s equally astounding she thinks she deserves a shred of pity from the British people.She has yet to convince us that she isn’t a threat to the UK.The Government must look at every legal avenue to ensure that she never sets foot in the UK again.THE Speaker John Bercow has allowed a bullying culture to grow unchecked in the Houses of Parliament.It now seems his handpicked Serjeant At Arms is one of the worst offenders. Will the Speaker take responsibility  Or just carry on, shameless as ever The other group of people who should be held accountable, of course, are the Remain MPs who turn a blind eye to Bercow’s incompetence because they believe he can help wreck Brexit.They should hang their heads in shame.IT’S a sign of the times that kids are more likely to hurt themselves on their Xbox than by exploring the great outdoors.Education Secretary Damian Hinds is one of many calling for kids to spend more time away from their screens.We heartily back his call — and schools and parents alike should listen.We reckon climbing trees is a lot more character-building than playing Fortnite.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: NewsBrexit: Just % of , EU regulations have been transferred to British lawBritain faces having "large gaps" in the law with just  days to go until BrexitShareCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical Correspondent:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB News "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBritain faces having “large gaps” in the law after Brexit after a study found just % of EU regulations have been replaced. Experts say it will create “troubling” uncertainty for businesses as they brace themselves for the possibility of no-deal in just over a month. Some , Brussels rules will have to be examined, edited and ‘retained’ by MPs before Britain leaves the EU at the end of March. To ensure a smooth transition, in either a deal or no-deal situation, the Government will “lt and sht”’ those Regulations which currently apply to the UK into the UK Statute book.   However, those Regulations need identying and many will need amending to make sense, and to be effective, post-Brexit. But with  days until Britain officially leaves the EU, new research found just , of the laws had been reviewed and amended so far. Charlotte Brady, Legislation Manager at Thomson Reuters, says: “Without fast and decisive action the UK may be left with large gaps or signicant inaccuracies in its Statue Book. “The Regulations identied as retained so far represent a tiny fraction of what needs to be reviewed and amended.” She added: “The uncertainty surrounding this is troubling for many businesses as it makes accurate planning more dficult.”

title: long standing labour mp newport
story: NewsPaul Flynn dead: Veteran Labour MP for Newport West dies aged Tributes have poured in from Jeremy Corbyn for the "independent thinker" who devoted his career to campaigning for causes like medicinal cannabisShareCommentsByJane LavenderDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsPaul Flynn, the veteran MP and medicinal cannabis campaigner, has died aged  "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailLabour stalwart and long-standing MP for Newport West Paul Flynn has died aged . Described as a giant of the Welsh Labour movement the long serving MP had been ill for some time. Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn paid tribute to his party colleague, saying he would be greatly missed. He added: Im very sad at the passing of my good friend Paul Flynn. He had such love for Newport, knowledge of radical South Wales history and a dry wit. He was an independent thinker who was a credit to the Labour Party. He will be greatly missed. Mr Flynn is a rebel who famously ed to the frontbench after  years in  for a brief spell in Jeremy Corbyns shadow cabinet.  He joked the decision to make him the oldest frontbencher since Gladstone was a ersity project to tackle the total absence of octogenarians. When he was sacked months later, he said: Our glorious leader, in an act of pioneering ersity, courageously decided to give opportunities for geriatrics on the front bench and this was so successful that he decided to create opportunities for geriatrics on the back bench. Im double blessed. The MP helped make a cup of cannabis tea on the House of Commons terrace for Elizabeth Brice, a multiple sclerosis sufferer who campaigned for medicinal cannabis before her death in . In  he urged people to break the law and use cannabis in Parliament in a drastic bid to change thinking in government. That’s the only way it’ll get through the common mind of the government which is set in concrete, he told MPs at the time. The whole law is evidence-free and prejudice-rich.  The MP has also led a charge against Acoba, the Whitehall watchdog that is supposed to police ministers and civil servants new jobs in the private sector after they leave office. Mr Flynn has branded the organisation futile. Asked for his favourite moment in  years, he told the Mirror in one of his final interviews: There have been a lot of them but I think its the satisfaction of representing the people in Newport. Ive never been a careerist politician... The most important thing is to smooth out the inequalities in le and give people who are short-changed a fair deal. The veteran MP announced he would step back formally from Parliament in October. He had not spoken in the House of Commons since February  after his long affliction with rheumatoid arthritis worsened. Mr Flynn, who has a , majority over the Tories in Newport West, said he would be standing down at the first opportunity, but stayed an MP to the end. He had indicated he would wait to seethere was a snap general election where he can quit with no cost to the taxpayer. His local association confirmed his death with a statement in Twitter. It said: Its with great sadness that we let you know that our MP, Paul Flynn, has died today. Paul is a hero to many of us in the Newport Labour family and we mourn for his familys loss. We would ask that the privacy of Pauls family is respected at this dficult time. And the First Minister of Wales and Welsh Labour leader Mark Drakeford said Mr Flynn was a giant of the Welsh Labour movement. He added: Todays news will be a source of great sadness to all those who knew him. He was one of the most effective communicators of his generation - inside the House of Commons and outside. But it was Pauls willingness to speak up for causes beyond the political mainstream which marked him out as a politician of real courage and integrity. I first met him more than  years ago, and it has been a privilege to have worked with him, in the run-up to the devolution era and beyond.

title: no deal brexit birds eye
story: NewsNo Deal Brexit: Birds Eye chief warns fish fingers face instant price hikeManaging director for the UK and Ireland, Wayne Hudson, singled out fish fingers as he warned the firm could face tarfs of up to %ShareCommentsByAndrew Woodcock:,  FEB NewsThe head of Birds Eye warned a no-deal Brexit will lead virtually instantaneously to price rises"Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA no-deal Brexit will lead virtually instantaneously to price rises on popular food products in shops, the head of Birds Eye in the UK has warned. The frozen food specialists managing director for the UK and Ireland, Wayne Hudson, said manufacturers would have to pass tarfs of up to % on to retailers, who would themselves have to decide how much of the extra cost to pass on to shoppers.Mr Hudson said the uncertainty around Brexit was seriously delaying our ambitious plans for continued growth and imposing additional costs, with four of the companys senior executives focused entirely on contingency planning.It remains unclear whether EU countries will be accommodating to exports of UK manufacturers products after Brexit, he warned. In an article in The Grocer magazine, Mr Hudson said: There is now a dense fog and a serious sense of unease that the entire food industry is having to navigate.  Here at Birds Eye, we are the strongest we have been in years. However, instead of focusing all our energy on making this business even better, an increasing and considerable amount of people and financial resource is being dedicated to Brexit contingency planning and ensuring continuity of supply. Speaking on BBC Radio s Today programme, Mr Hudson said: If we crash out on March  without a deal it does mean that World Trade Organisation tarfs will be applied. If you look at our portfolio of goods, that could range from anywhere between % and %. That is a signicant new cost. We buyfishon a global basis, we makefishfingersin our factory in Germany and we bring those into the UK. We want to continue our investment story, we want to continue to grow our business and expand our capacity. But where we place those investments, with the current situation and the fiasco around Brexit, we cant decide where to do it until we get clarity.  Mr Hudson said that food manufacturers cannot control prices charged for their products by retailers in shops. But he added: If we are faced with substantial tarfs we will have to pass those tarfs on, and in turn our customers will need to decide whether or not they pass those on to consumer and shopper. Retailers are warning that there isnt the margin in the supply chain to absorb any more tarfs, he said. Writing in The Grocer, Mr Hudson dismissed claims from pro-Brexit politicians that warnings of the possible effects of EU withdrawal without an agreement amounted to scaremongering. The brutal fact is that,we leave the EU without a deal, food prices will increase virtually instantaneously as WTO tarfs would apply, he said. Scaremongering  Absolutely not. Whats really scary are the politicians who claim it is. For low-income families most vulnerable to food price increases a no-deal Brexit holds no positive outcome - a fact that politicians seem to be ignoring in their self-serving posturing, he said.

title: pregnant teen universal credit faced
story: NewsPregnant teen on Universal Credit faced starvation - then something incredible happenedJaedyn Overbury and Lizzie Mason were struggling on Universal Credit after moving out of a Birmingham YMCAShareByStephanie BallooMilo Boyd:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video struggling-universal-credit-teen-feared-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A teen couple expecting their first baby were fearing weeks of hunger on Universal Credit before something amazing happeed.Jaedyn Overbury and Lizzie Mason, both , hit hard times after moving out of a YMCA homeless shelter and into a house share in Erdington, Birmingham.The cash-strapped couple lived off dry toast for three days after Jaedyn was signed off sick from his job stacking shelves atASDA with General Anxiety Disorder, Birmingham Live reports.The pound they received each month through Universal Credit soon vanished on rent, smart price food, phone top-ups and public transport back and forth to hospital appointments.   With weeks of nothing but a few slices of bread stretching out in front of the engaged couple and their unborn baby, Jaedyn put out a desperate plea to their new community. The response from kind-hearted locals was astonishing. As soon as his request for advice about food banks began to circulate online residents rallied together to donate a huge hamper of food. Where before they had the bare essentials, the couple quickly found themselves with a fridge full of bacon, fruit, soup, pasta, crisps, bread and dozens of tins, as well as eggs, milk, butter and cheese. The pair said the food haul will last them up to two months and will help four-weeks pregnant Lizzie to enjoy a healthy pregnancy.   Jaedyn said: I was amazed by the response we got, we didnt expect it at all. We had food from about three people, picked up by one of the ladies and dropped to us all on the first night that we had put the post up. And then from there to yesterday we have had four more people drop food to us. While doctors have recommended that the teen should not work at the moment, he is still looking for a job to make ends meet.   Jaedyn continued: The universal rate for being signed off is awful to live on so Im still looking for part time work, even when advised by the doctors not to be in work for the time being. I struggle quite badly with Generalized Anxiety Disorder and I also have problems with my chest and breathing which makes physical tasks dficult, still waiting on x-ray and blood results to figure out why my breathing is so limited. I can barely make it up a set of stairs without gasping for air so any physically job wouldnt work. As well as the food the couple received plenty of advice as to which food banks to go to and how to get vouchers.   Jaedyns heartbreaking appeal on the Erdington community group on Sunday, February  read: Me and my misses are new to areaand we have been here for about four months now. We have moved into a house share of four people and unfortunately due to having a shared kitchen keep having our food vanish out the freezer. We have informed our support staff but they can only recommend calling policeWe have completely run out of food and we dont get any money between us until Thursday . We want to know where the nearest food bank is and how to get vouchers for it  My misses is pregnant and I dont want her to go without anything to eat for the next week, possibly month. We are really struggling with finding something to eat. We both dont have contact with family and no friends in the area, its just the two of us.

title: cooking sunday roast exposes people
story: NewsCooking Sunday roast exposes people to more toxic air than polluted city streetHeating and burning food produces particles that are inhaled and may increase your chances of developing a deadly diseaseShareCommentsByMartin BagotHealth and Science Correspondent:,  FEB NewsYour beloved roast dinner is filling your lungs with toxic air comparable to traffic exhausts, scientists say "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailCooking a roast can expose people to more toxic air thanthey stood on a polluted city street, warn experts. They found fumes from the meal were  times more polluting than a London roadside and  times over World Health Organisation safe outdoor limits. The shock levels were far higher than expected by scientists. Tests detected tiny particles, PM.s, that are inhaled and linked to heart disease, stroke and lung cancer, which contribute to , early deaths in Britain each year. Over a day, in a purpose-built home in Austin, Texas, the HOMEChem project produced and tested meals such as a full English breakfast, a vegetable stir fry for lunch, roast turkey for dinner and pies for dessert.  WHO safe limits of  micrograms of PM. per cubic metre were exceeded for eight-and-a-half hours out of the . Heating and burning during cooking produces particles, with some food producing more than others. A roast turkey dinner saw pollution levels hit  micrograms per cubic metre. The most PM.s appeared to be produced when Brussels sprouts were charred.  A similar cooking style for vegetables in stir fries was just as polluting as cooked meats. Burning fats in meat or adding them to frying and roast pans also gave high levels. Other sources of PM.s were oils left on electric hobs, heated saucepans and open flames on gas stoves. High levels generally lingered for about an hour after the cooker was used. Even putting two pieces of bread in a toaster produced  micrograms which stayed in the air for about  minutes afterwards. Lead researcher Prof Marina Vance, of the University of Colorado, said: “We were all a bit shocked when we saw our first measurement.  This is the most comprehensive ever assessment of chemistry in a home. These high-end instruments have never really been used to detect pollution levels indoors.” Levels detected dwarfed our Government’s Air Quality Index highest warning rating for outdoors. When there are - micrograms per cubic metre the public is warned to avoid strenuous exercise outdoors. The results were unveiled at the shyAmerican Association for the Advancement of Science in Washington, D.C.  Prof Vance said studies are linking long-term exposure to particles with brain ageing and increased stress levels. Leading British pollution expert Prof Ian Colbeck, of Essex University, said: “A roast is one of the worst ways of cooking as regards indoor air pollution. “However once you stop cooking, concentrations shygradshyshyuallyto background levels.” The AAAS also heard that children in homes with vinyl floors had far higher levels of polybrominated diphenyl ethers — toxic, fire retardant compounds — in their blood.   Always cook using the extractor fan The shock findings of the HOMEChem study has sparked an urgent call to families to ventilate their kitchens. Prof Marina Vance said: “We’ve been telling ourselves ‘boil everything, don’t roast’ but roasts are just too delicious.”   The researchers advise while cooking to: open windows always use extractor fans and hobs at the back of the cooker keep your cooker and pans clean of oils heat on as low a temperature as possible and boiling food on electric hobs is best. Prof Vance said: “Use an exhaust hood, try to ventilate your home while you’re cooking. That’s really my prime piece of advice. “Before, I only used the oven hood ventilatorI was cooking something smelly. Now I put it on for everything.”

title: mum 27 takes life days
story: NewsMum, , takes own le days after shes drugged and raped by sex beasts who filmed it allJenna Johnson was found dead at her Thurso, Scotland home days after two men threatened to publish the video - taunting her that shed lose her kidsShareByMarcello Mega:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsThe -year-olds body was found at her home in Thurso "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum-of-two took her own le because she was drugged and raped by sex beasts who filmed the attack. Jenna Johnson died on January  however her family believe that the horric ordeal days earlier was the catalyst. The -year-olds body was found at her home in Thurso, Scotland after she failed to join her family for lunch at her mum’s house. Jenna was said to have been tormented by the thought of people in her home town finding out about the assault, report the Daily Record. After Jenna’s body was found, it was taken to Glasgow for a forensic examination. But tests were inconclusive because the sexual assault by two men happened days earlier, on the night of December  or early hours of December . Jenna told close friends and her little sister Ky the shyidentities of the two men who drove her to kill herself. Now her family wants justice.  And Ky and mum Carol Forrest have reached out to another Caithness family still demanding justice after more than five years. One of the men Jenna accused of rape is suspected locally to have murdered Stefan Sutherland, , in September , and to have got away with it. Police and the Crown Office continue to claim there were no suspicious circumstances surrounding Stefan’s death, despite a catalogue of evidence to the contrary. Stefan vanished after a night out in Lybster, Caithness, on September , . His body was found on the beach at nearby Occumster on September .  His blood was found on the walls of the suspect’s home and he had injuries consistent with being tortured when he was found. Carol said: “We know, and our whole community knows, that these two guys are evil and have carried out other sickening and violent crimes. “Stefan’s killer is the shyringleader. He thinks he is above the law and is a very dangerous man. He needs to be locked up or there will be more deaths.” Stefan’s dad Sandy said: “This guy should have been in jail for Stefan’s murder andhe had been, another family would not be suffering as we have.”  About a week before she died, Jenna had woken to find herself covered in bruises and scratches, with needle marks in one arm. As her head cleared, she recalled being seriously shysexually assaulted by one man and raped by another. The two told her they had filmed the attack and shythreatened to publish the video, taunting her that it would lead to the loss of her children. She showed Ky, , her arms after the assault.  Ky said: “One arm had needle marks and the other was covered in scrapes and bruises that looked like they had been made by fingers holding her down. “She didn’t tell me the full story but she told me who she had been with and I knew one of them was considered a murderer in our community. “She said she must have been drugged as she couldn’t remember clearly all that had happened. “I was actually angry at her for associating with them. “Over the Christmas period, she was subdued and quiet. But on Hogmanay, she brightened up, ordered a shymicrowave, things for the kids, shyornaments, candles and we talked about taking a winter trip together to Iceland and a summer holiday in New York.”  Carol added: “Jenna was not suicidal when she left her kids with me on Hogmanay. “Who orders things for their home and plans holidays when they intend to end their le  “In the morning, when I texted, ‘Happy New Year’ and she never replied, I got a bad feeling. She was coming to me to eat but she didn’t show and there was no sign of her on Facebook.” Worried, she called the police and two officers went with her and broke into Jenna’s flat, finding her dead inside. Later that day, Carol and Ky heard a full account of what Jenna had apparently gone through from friends. Ky said: “It seemed a few people in the community knew these two guys had drugged and raped her and filmed it, because they had actually been boasting about it. “They told Jenna they had filmed themselves doing sexual things to her and were shythreatening to send it to people, saying she’d lose her kids. “I don’t knowthey were blackmailing her or just enjoying having power over her but she was distraught. “Jenna was a loyal friend and totally devoted to her kids. “The thought of losing them would have been too much for her.” Her mum added: “I’m so angry with both these men. One is the ringleader and nothing about him surprises anyone who knows him but Jenna trusted the other one as a friend and he betrayed her.” The family has been told Jenna was drinking with the men when they turned on her, held her down and injected her with a sedative. Breaking down, Ky recounted how Jenna described the rape. She said: “We have told the police and the people she confided in have also made statements identying the men who did this, and they are both well known to the police. “We have no ideathey have been shyquestioned but we have been told that no video footage has been found and that they have been unable to access Jenna’s phone because it had a passcode. “Police told us it could cost pound to have an expert bypass the security and they would have to justy the cost to their bosses. “My sister was raped, threatened with public humiliation and I don’t know what  and she has killed herself as a result. “I don’t think you can put a price on doing everything possible to gather evidence to deliver justice.” Carol added: “The police appeared at first to want to push as hard as they could. “But we feel that it’s already been downgraded. There should be no argument about the phone being examined, no matter the cost. “Jenna was out with friends at a house party after leaving me on New Year’s Eve. They all say she was in good form. “She got a phone call and became agitated, but didn’t say who called or what it was about. “A text followed and her mood got even worse. When her friends moved on to another party, she wanted to go home. “She called me at about .am and told me to tell her kids she really loved them. I was half asleep and thinking she could tell them herself when she came for her dinner. “I didn’t realise there was anything major wrong and that it would be the last time we spoke. “The most important thing I can do now for my daughter is look after her children. “But I can also demand justice. She doesn’t have a voice any more so we have to speak for her. Too many serious and violent crimes have been swept under the carpet in this area in recent years. “Ky and I need to make sure this isn’t another one. “We want people to know how Jenna died and to know that eventhe men who raped and threatened her didn’t kill her with their own hands, they are responsible. “We won’t be fobbed off and we won’t stay quiet. “I had to bury my daughter two weeks after her th birthday. Our lives will never be the same. We are devastated. “Yet they remain free to walk around and choose their next victim.” Police said there were no shysuspicious circumstances surrounding Jenna’s death but refused to give further comment as there was an “ongoing investigation”. If you need to speak to someone, Samaritans are available   by calling   or by emailing jo@samaritans.org

title: poof princess diana not pregnant
story: NewsProof that Princess Diana was NOT pregnant at the time of her deathForensic scientist Angela Gallop examined Princess Diana, the Princess of Wales, after the fatal car crash in Paris in August ShareCommentsByLaura Forsyth:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsMs Gallop claims to have taken a sample of Princess Dianas stomach contents "Get the biggest Royal Family stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA forensic scientist has revealed how she quashed rumours that Princess Diana was pregnant at the time of her death. It was speculated that at the time of the tragic Paris car crash that the late People’s Princess was expecting lover Dodi Fayad’s child. But Angela Gallop, whose career spans over  years, claims to have taken a sample of the -year-old’s stomach contents. And she explained that there were two key areas involved in the high profile investigation. She told The Sunday Times: The first was to seethe blood samples taken from Diana contained any of the pregnancy hormonehuman chorionic gonadotropin . The second was to look for any evidence that she might have been taking a contraceptive pill. The expert has written about her findings in her new book, When the dogs dont bark: A forensic scientists search for the truth. Professor David Cowan, former head of forensic science at Kings College in London led the forensic investigation to establishDiana was expecting her third child at the time of the crash.   At the time, Prof. Cowan said that blood transfusions desperately needed to save the Princess complicated pregnancy tests post-mortem, which meant that stomach contents were used to find the truth instead.Ms Gallop added: “So the best sample for testing was some blood that had been recovered from the carpet in the footwell of her seat in the Mercedes.” She confirmed that the results came out negative which means that it was very unlikely that Diana was pregnant at the time of the crash.  This reportedly matched up with information given by those close to Diana that there had been no other evidence to suggest she was pregnant. The late princess was with Dodi al-Fayed and driver Henri Paul when the car crashed in the Pont DAlma tunnel in Paris on August , .   Seven years later Sir John Stevens, the commissioner of the politan police, was asked to investigate several questions. One of these questions included: Diana pregnant at the time of her death  Another questions asked was: Did the blood sample attributed to Henri Paul actually come from him  And was there any valid justication for the elimination of a white Fiat Uno car from involvement in the collision  When the dogs dont bark: A forensic scientists search for the truth by Professor Angela Gallop is to be published by Hodder and Stoughton on Thursday and costs pound

title: uks first vegan cheesemonger opens
story: NewsUKs first vegan cheesemonger opens but dairy farmers arent happy it uses the C wordLa Fauxmagerie has opened in south London but Dairy UK has written in objection at the use of the word cheeseShareCommentsByIsabel Dobinson:,  FEB NewsCharlotte Stevens has opened the business in south London "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBritains first fully vegan cheesemonger been criticised by dairy farmers within days of opening for business - for using the word cheese. La Fauxmagerie, in Brixton, south London, sells artisan cheeses made from plant-based sources. It is the first totally vegan cheese store to open in the UK. But the dairy industry want to stop the shop branding plant-based products as cheese saying it is misleading to shoppers. The sisters who launched the business branded Dairy UKs claims both ridiculous and unnecessary. Rachel Stevens, , opened La Fauxmagerie with her -year-old sister, Charlotte.   The shop was hailed a huge success with vegans travelling far and wide to check out the new award-winning dairy free cheddar, camembert, mozzarella and halloumi on offer. The sisters, originally from a rural village in south Wales, ditched their day jobs to launch the business. But within days the independent business in the Brixton Village complex has ruffled feathers. The industrys trade association, Dairy UK, has accused the sisters of misleading customers by labelling vegan goods as cheese. But Rachel says the dairy giants claim discredits and underestimates the intelligence of their customers.   She said: Its clear in the name of our business that we are selling dairy free products - its a pun. Our tagline also clearly states we are a plant based cheese monger. We are not misleading and the claim that we are discredits the consumers and underestimates the intelligence of our customers. It all seems a little unnecessary, people are generally aware that plant based means non-dairy. Peanut butter doesnt include butter and when people ask for a soy latte at Costa, they ask for soya milk - not blended soya beans.  The former Marks and Spencer merchandise worker said: We expected some attention because we knew wed be the first in the country, but we didnt expect to ruffle feathers. Dairy UK sent a letter to the shop. We are going to take things as they come. I understand people might be sceptical because the food culture in the UK is very meat heavy. Rachel who moved to Balham, south London, four years ago only became a fully fledged vegan last month. But she and her lactose intolerant sister began plans to open their own dairy free business last autumn. Dairy UK has been contacted for comment.
