title: scottish-airline-loganair-steps-in-to-save-key-flybmi-routes
story: The Scottish operator will provide flights from Aberdeen to Bristol, Oslo and Esbjerg, replacing services previously provided by Flybmi.It comes after the East-Midlands based airline announced on Saturday that it had ceased operations and filed for administration because of Brexit ldquouncertainty and ldquospikes in fuel and carbon costs.Read moreWhat Flybmi are telling customers to dothey have a bookingLoganair said it would provide daily services Monday to Friday between Aberdeen and Esjberg - which is Denmarkrsquos fth largest city - making this the airlinersquos first service to the country.Meanwhile, flights between Aberdeen and Oslo and the service from Aberdeen to Bristol will operate on weekdays as well as Sundays.Loganair already operates  flights a week from Aberdeen Airport.The airlinersquos managing director Jonathan Hinkles said: ldquoItrsquos always really sad to see an airline go out of business and our thoughts are with all those affected - particularly staff members.ldquoWersquore working on employment opportunities for pilots, cabin crew and engineering support staff to strengthen the Loganair team.He added: ldquoThere is no doubt that trading is tough but Loganair is - we believe - in the strongest position of any UK regional airline.ldquoWersquove done a lot of work over the last two years to secure our future as an independent regional airline and despite the challenges posed by fuel and carbon costs, and Brexit, we are strongly placed to take up new opportunities as they arise.ldquoOur three new routes from Aberdeen complement our existing activity across a distinct geographical area, acting as a logical fit with our network - while also markedly increasing the airlinersquos presence in Aberdeen.Read moreLoganair chief warns of more airline failuresIt is understood , passengers had been scheduled to travel with Flybmi, which has a total of  employees, on Sunday.Scot Caroline Stewart recently moved from Aberdeen to Esbjerg in Denmark and had been due to visit family and friends in Aberdeen next month.ldquoMy best friend is getting married next month so I was heading home for her hen party and her wedding and itrsquos also my grandarsquos th birthday party, she told BBC Scotland before Loganairrsquos announcement.She added: ldquoWe didnrsquot use a credit card, we just used a debit card and it will be too expensive for us to rebook.ldquoThere was absolutely no warning. My husband only booked his flight two days ago and the money has been taken out of his account.Customers have been advised to contact their payment card issuer to get a refund for flights, while those who have booked through a travel agent or partner airlines are advised to contact their agent or airline for details of their options.A Flybmi statement said: ldquoThe airline has faced several dficulties, including recent spikes in fuel and carbon costs, the latter arising from the EUrsquos recent decision to exclude UK airlines from full participation in the Emissions Trading Scheme.ldquoCurrent trading and future prospects have also been seriously affected by the uncertainty created by the Brexit process, which has led to our inability to secure valuable flying contracts in Europe and lack of confidence around bmirsquos ability to continue flying between destinations in Europe.ldquoWe sincerely regret that this course of action has become the only option open to us, but the challenges, particularly those created by Brexit, have proven to be insurmountable.

title: baptiste-review-new-detective-series-was-it-much-cop
story: After two series of The Missing we have grown accustomed to Julien Baptistersquos craggy face, but has he done enough to stand with the rest of the second name only squad  On the evidence of this, the first of six episodes of The Missing spin-off, Irsquoll take the option of gazing into the middle distance for a ponder.Baptiste, played by Tcheky Karyo, did a lot of that. Grey of hair and beard, he wore his wistfulness on his sleeve, like a sad Santa or a down in the dumps Gandalf. When we last saw the Frenchman he was suffering from a brain tumour and heading for the operating theatre, fate uncertain. When we meet him again he is in Amsterdam with we Celia celebrating the birth of their first grandchild.Also in Amsterdam is an Englishman, Edward Strattonwho is looking for his missing niece, Natalie, a drug addict. The local police commissioner asks Baptiste to help with the case. Of course she does. Poor old Baptiste cannot go anywhere without being drafted in by the local coppers. Like Michael Corleone, just when he thinks he is out of the missing person business, they pull him back in.Read more:Alison Rowat: So much for the Question Time queries, where are the answers ldquoWersquove got no-one  with your experience, says the chief, a ldquofriend of Baptistersquos from long ago. Writers Harry and Jack Williams have promised that this series will be in part about exploring Baptistersquos past, so put that fact down: was once in love with Amsterdam police chief. It might be important.It would have been the wise viewer who kept notes in general, because the first instalment scattered plot lines left, right, and centre. Baptiste set about gathering clues, pausing every now and then to deliver a plaintive aside. ldquoI do not feel as I did," was one. ldquoHuman feeling is a mystery," was another. All right mate, donrsquot go on, therersquos a missing woman to find.Stratton insisted on tagging along, even though he had already taken Nataliersquos photo around the De Wallen district, where the local ladies like to take their clothes off to give the windows a good clean .Baptiste spotted they were being followed. It is skills like that which explain why he is so in demand. After an unfeasibly long chase in which a paunchy Stratton and a limping Baptiste manage to catch a young guy, it seemed as though they had hit on a break.Read more:Alison Rowat: Smart move Dyson, too badthe rest of us think it sucksDonrsquot speak too soon. The Williams boys are not done yet. Now we are in a cellar with a lot of unhappy women next itrsquos a bulb field where a German Shepherd, merrily tiptoeing through the tulips, has found something worth digging up. What is going on  My money is on people trafficking, which will be unfortunateit turns out to be the case, because Shetland is currently digging in that area like a curious Alsatian. As for the multiple plot lines, either the Williams brothers are going to successfully navigate their way out of this maze, or Baptiste is going to be as irritatingly confusing as their last drama, Rellik.The viewersrsquo only hope in making sense of it all is Baptiste. Our crumpled hero has found the missing before, made the impossible possible, through instinct, doggedness, and beaucoup Gallic charm, and he can do so again. He might need to cut back on that pondering, though,he is to solve the case before Christmas.

title: david-pratt-uk-must-accept-responsibility-for-its-nationals-who-joined-is
story: But on one issue at least Irsquom in agreement with the US President: his call to Americarsquos European allies to take back  Islamic Statefighters captured in Syria makes sound sense.Before I explain the reasons why, letrsquos just for a moment take stock of the current situation on the ground in eastern Syria.As I write, the Kurdish-led Syrian Democratic Forcesbacked by the US military are poised to capture ISrsquos last, tiny enclave, bringing its selfdeclared caliphate to an end.By any standards the fall of Baghouz is a signicant moment.It ends ISrsquos grand project launched from the great medieval mosque of Mosul in northern Iraq in , when Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi seized advantage of regional chaos to proclaim himself caliph, suzerain over all Muslim people and land.In the years that followed, he and his cadres would go on to set up a barbarous governing system ndash with courts, a currency and flag ndash which, at its height, stretched from north-west Syria almost to Baghdad, encompassing some two million inhabitants.It was a reign of terror the hallmarks of which were massacres, sexual slavery and the beheading of hostages.Ever since , however, a forceful international military response has pushed ISrsquos caliphate steadily back to the point where only a few hundred of its fighters now remain in the enclave of Baghouz on the Euphrates.The SDF has already confirmed that most of those remaining fighters are foreigners.Those who do not die fighting will be taken prisoner, which brings me back to Mr Trumprsquos call for Europe to take back its nationals who became jihadist fighters.Prone to exaggeration, Mr Trump might be over-egging it somewhat in suggesting thatEurope fails to do so there may be no alternative at some time in the future but to release them.That is not going to happen. Short of a calamitous sht in the military dynamic on the ground whereby the Kurds find themselves preoccupied with, say, advancing Turkish forces and are hard pressed to concentrate on securing the IS prisoners, they will remain incarcerated.Quite simply, itrsquos in no onersquos interests ndash least of all Washingtonrsquos ndash to have hundreds of jihadi fighters back in circulation.That said, therersquos no doubt the Kurds are currently struggling to cope with the responsibility of holding perhaps , IS detainees, many of them foreign fighters from up to  countries.ldquoWe canrsquot do it alone, was how it was summed up recently by Abdulkarim Omar, a leader of the Kurdish-led foreign-relations commission, which is affiliated with the US-backed SDF.ldquoEveryone is running away from the responsibility, he insisted.Like others who have visited this part of eastern Syria, I can vouch for the fact that the Kurdsrsquo fledgling administration lacks the resources and capacity to put on trial, or detain indefinitely, so many people.The Kurds then are right when they say they should not be left to shoulder this burden. Aside from recognising this, there are very sound, pragmatic and strategic reasons why it would make sense for Europe to take back its fighters.Mr Trump alluded to this last weekend when he said that the US doesnrsquot want to stand by and watch as IS fighters ldquopermeate Europe, which is where they are expected to go.While not all those fighters being held in eastern Syria are of European origin, many are. The prospect of them at some point being able to move around freely again, perhaps making their way illegally to Europe or rejoining the global ranks of IS or a similar organisation, is worrying to say the least.No doubt this was very much on the mind of the head of Britainrsquos Secret Intelligence Service , Alex Younger, when he warned ISrsquos threat is likely to ldquomorph and spread and that its threat is ldquodefinitely not done while attending the Munich security conference over the last few days.Mr Younger also cautioned about showing triumphalism at the demise of IS, something Mr Trump, of course, is already doing by declaring a ldquo per cent victory.This is where Mr Trump is wrong and, indeed, his triumphalism flies in the face of a recent report by his own US Department of Defence that warns an ldquoeffective, clandestine IS organisation appears to be taking hold.In describing the future course of IS, counter-terrorism officials speak of an ldquoatomised, clandestine network of cells with a decentralised chain of command.This is the reality faced on the ground so, while Mr Trump is wrong to talk of all-out ldquovictory, hersquos right in voicing concerns over the potential capacity of IS fighters currently detained being recycled into the jihadi cause and ranks.For this reason alone the British Governmentrsquos reluctance to take back UK nationals who have served with IS or supported their ranks in Syria and Iraq is incredibly short sighted.Evidently, itrsquos at odds too with the kind of thinking expressed by Britainrsquos head of overseas intelligence.As its stands, the options are simple. Either run the risk of leaving those UK nationals in Syria and them rejoining IS as it goes back to its roots and re-galvanises itself as an insurgency ndash or bring them back.In so doing they would effectively be taken out of circulation and an opportunity to glean invaluable intelligence gained. Adding to these considerations too is recognising the importance of having those accused of atrocities stand trial and,convicted, facing punishment.Time and again IS has shown its capacity for strategic retreats in hard times only to rebound when circumstances change.As the MI chief made clear a few days ago: ldquoThe military defeat of the caliphate does not represent the end of the terrorist threat that we face.Itrsquos time the UK Government woke up and recognised the long-term implications of any decision it makes not to bring back its nationals who fought for the jihadists.Itrsquos time it listened to Mr Trump on that point at least, evenit should ignore his boast of ldquovictory over IS.

title: letters-the-eu-has-much-less-to-lose-from-a-no-deal-brexit-than-the-uk
story: The main problem with a no-deal Brexit is that apart from seeing a large fleet of lorries assembled in an airfield in Kent we have no idea as to how a no-deal Brexit will impact on the UK. We are assured that we will simply revert to the position that applied in  prior to joining the EU and that it will be a simple matter of implementing World Trade Organisation rules.As far as the European Union is concerned it will be relatively simple to deal with a no-deal Brexit since the United Kingdom will be added to the list of countries not in the union and trade terms that currently apply to non-member countries will then apply to the UK. In the case of the UK we presumably will want to reap the benefit of being able to trade with the entire worldwithout the restrictions currently imposed by the EU. I have still to hear details of the arrangements that will be put in place in order to comply with World Trade Organisation rules and secure the benefits that Dennis Forbes Grattonclaims will boost the Scotch whisky sales.Sandy Gemmill, Warriston Gardens, Edinburgh."NO deal is better than a bad deal", Theresa May told us at the start. That was on June , , almost three years ago. What has been done in all that time to prepare for leaving without a deal  She has never told us. It should have been straightforward to begin then to prepare for that event given the acknowledged determination of the EU to punish us for leaving, expressed the world over, even in the papers produced by Michel Barnier  Co, asit were proper conduct and only changed when complained of. Of course, they intended to punish us for leaving to discourage other EU countries from following us. Time and again the hysterical Remainers have grabbed the floor to terry everyone into some kind of deal, even a bad one. Yet a no deal Brexit was the strongest card in our hand. The one that might have ensured a deal that made sense.Instead, the deal she has been forced to accept and they now refuse to alter is completely unworkable, ties us hand and foot and leaves us far worse off than we were before we decided to leave. That was not what we voted to leave for.Most of the decisions have yet to be settled. Disputes are to be resolved by the EU court asits impartiality is a given. Nonsense! No court on the planet is ever wholly impartial and in this case, the EU will give us a few crumbs to suggest fairness while keeping the plums for themselves. Emmanuel Macron has already refused to sign unless Frenchmen are allowed to continue to fish our waters. The Spanish want Gibraltar and wont sign unless they get it. They have said this and they have a veto over the deal along with every one of the others, whose price may yet be even worse. This has been swept under the carpet, like the redactions in the "summary" of legal advice the government wanted hidden and only released the full document when forced to do so in December , bringing about the Government being held in contempt ndash the first time in  years. Morally, that was a disgrace. Mrs May has led the worst government in forty years! And it continues, day after day, so that we cannot recognise our Parliament as anything but a shambles. Her Government has failed and is heading for the wire, hoping that enough frightened MPs will allow her rotten deal to be voted for.She set out to lead the country to leave the EU. She was resolute, polite and that was not good enough. The men in the EU played with her like cats with a mouse. All she can hope for is to be known as the worst Prime Minister in history: the one who set out to free us of the EU and left us worse off than we had ever been. There is only one thing to do: leave with no deal. Then and only then can we secure our freedom to make deals the world over, control our borders, our fisheries and colonies like Gibraltar, that rightly view themselves as British. We need to show our courage brace ourselves to be at our best again. No deal is no disaster but an opportunity to control our own destiny.William Scott, Argyle Place, Rothesay.ON October , , Enoch Powell pleaded with the delegates to the Tory Party Conference in Brighton to reject entry to what was to become the European Union, saying: "I do not believe that this nation, which has maintained and defended its independence for a thousand years, will now submit to see it merged or lost. Nor did I become a member of sovereign parliament in order to consent to that sovereignty being abated or transferred."He, unfortunately, was a voice crying in the wilderness.However, the portents of the demise of the EU are increasing daily across the "Community". In a few years there will be nothing to leave. Better we leave now than go down with the wreckage of this dreadful experiment.George Murray,  Dundonald Road, Troon.POST- Germany set about a process called ldquoBewaumlltigung der Vergangenheit", overcoming its history, coming to terms with its past ndash honestly and openly. The latest salvos against Churchill in Scotland and in England are exactly that. The Brexit issue has forced many to look at the assumptions, myths and claims about the UK and its past. The recalling of the ldquoDunkirk spirit and other glib half-truths are bringing this reassessment of the past into focus and discussion. The origin-myths of the UK are being subjected to critical comment.As the European Continent gazes in wonder at the antics in the English Commons and its historical procedures carried over into the UK post-, it is time for an honest reappraisal of ldquoour God-who-made-thee-mighty-past.John Edgar,a Langmuir Quadrant, Kilmaurs.

title: mark-smith-the-39-steps-plan-and-how-a-third-way-on-independence-could-win-support-from-a-forgotten-type-of-nationalist
story: Most of us, I imagine, will have felt something similar to Hannay at some point: the power of the Scottish landscape to make us feel better. But isnrsquot it a shame Scotlandrsquos politics rarely has the same effect  Instead, in the last few days, this blessed country has seen yet more bitter debate about nationalism and the views of one nationalist in particular, Andrew Wilson. Mr Wilson, you will remember, was the man behind the SNPrsquos Growth Commission last year, so we should pay attention.The most controversial bit of Mr Wilsonrsquos most recent pronouncement for hard nationalists is his support for ldquosoft independence. Some nationalists would like to move immediately to a Marxist state, he says, but the party should try to create a  for a softer independence that might win broad support. ldquoThe reality, he says, ldquois change of such signicance in any organisation, let alone a major country, is a process rather than an event.Mr Wilson does not go into great detail about what he means by a soft break-up, but I think he may be onto something and, strangely, I think The Thirty-Nine Steps and John Buchan can help. Most fans of Buchan know he had a strong romantic bond with his homeland ndash you can tell that from the descriptions of Galloway in The Thirty-Nine Steps they may also know that he once said, ldquoevery Scotsman should be a Scottish nationalist. But the important point is he was a very particular type of nationalist and, crucially for Mr Wilsonrsquos idea of soft independence, itrsquos one that still exists in great numbers today.The speech Buchan gave during a debate in the Commons in  while he was an MP gives a more detailed idea of his views. The subject was home rule for Scotland, which at the time was attracting more supportand in the end, Buchan told the Commons he did not back a Scottish parliament. However, he also said thatit could be proved it would be advantageous, then Scots should support it.Read More:Andrew Wilson: SNP should back soft version of independenceThis is a pretty clear example of the kind of nationalism Buchan preferred: you might call it patriotic pragmatism, although perhaps therersquos a better way to describe a slice of Scottish opinion that has been somewhat forgotten. In a new biography of her grandfather to be published in April, Ursula Buchan also attempts to capture the novelistrsquos views and settles on an interesting description. John Buchan wasnrsquot a unionist, she says, but he wasnrsquot a nationalist either. He was a ldquounionist nationalist with concentric, not warring, loyalties.I realise that in the current climate, ldquounionist nationalist is a confusing term, but I also think itrsquos the right one for Buchan and other Scots with similar views. Not only that, I think the SNP is unlikely to attract greater support until they better understand how ldquounionist nationalists think. Thankfully, Buchanrsquos  speech is helpful in this regard because he explains it perfectly.First of all, the unionist nationalist is just as likely as any SNP supporter to have romantic views about Scotland ndash in Buchanrsquos words, nationalism on romantic or historical grounds is ldquoperfectly respectable. The unionist nationalist is also likely to believe decisions about Scotland should be made in Scotland or with Scotlandrsquos consent. To quote Buchan again,therersquos something wrong with Scotland, itrsquos the business of Scots to put it right.However, Scots in the mould of Buchan are not just nationalists, theyrsquore internationalists and they would reject putting a nationrsquos interests first whatever the consequences, as in ldquoAmerica First or ldquoScotland First. Buchan put it this way: ldquoit would be a bad dayScottish MPs ever came to support a measure which was for the moment good for Scotland, but was demonstrably bad for England hellip or the world. This is a critical point and explains why the SNPrsquos ldquoStanding up for Scotland slogan rings hollow for some voters.Which brings us to possibly the most important quality of the unionist nationalist, which is that they keep their romantic nature in balance with their pragmatic side and make decisions on what they see as the economic facts. Buchan said Scotland was a nation in the closest corporate alliance with her southern neighbour, and that to attempt to separate them would be a costly blunder. ldquoI do not believe, he said, ldquoand no Scotsman believes, in spending money without a proper .Read More:Joanna Cherry joins attack on softest possible independence planIn writing his report last year, Andrew Wilson seems to have understand all of this his awareness of the concerns of those who might be described as unionist nationalists also explains his call for slow progress towards a soft independence ndash the question is how soft it has to be. Admittedly, some unionist nationalists will never support complete independence, particularlyit is done precipitately, but perhaps they could be persuaded to support something lighter, a third way in which Scotland loosens the ties of the union until the point where it would be economically harmful ndash in other words, it would remain at least as close to the rest of the UK as the UK used to be with EU, although possibly much closer.I realise Mr Wilson has something much more like traditional independence in mind, but I think he should at least give John Buchanrsquos speech a read. Among other things, Buchan warned against ldquoarticial nationalism which manufactures dferences, but more importantly he promoted ldquosane nationalism based on what is economically good for the country. At the time, many Scots would have agreed with him. I think many Scots still do.

title: in-pictures-peter-capaldi-delights-fans-at-charity-signing
story: The former Doctor Who star spent nine hours meeting  fans in Edinburgh over the weekend, stopping only once for a -minute break.Capaldi was appearing at Capital Sci-Fi Con, anot-for-profit sci-fi, movie and pop culture event which raises money Childrenrsquos Hospices Across Scotland .Donatinghis entire autograph fee to CHAS, the actor stayed an hour after the convention had closed on Saturday to meet fans who had queued to see him.He even treated fans to a rendition of David Bowies Star Man on the guitar.#PeterCapaldi playing Starman by David Bowie on #CapitalSciFiCon in Edinburgh##part ## I died@supportCHAS pic edpAeohGSOther from the weekend include special appearances from Star Wars and Harry Potter star Warwick Davis and Scottish comics talent like Frank Quitely and Gary Erskine.Laura Campbell, Senior CHAS Community Fundraiser, said: ldquoKeith and his team of lsquocauseplayersrsquo are a phenomenal group of fundraisers. Through their infectious passion for all things sci-fi and giving back to the community, over the years theyrsquove managed to raise over pound, for CHAS. The total raised from this weekend is still being counted, but we expect it to top last yearrsquos pound,.Read more:Doctor Whos Peter Capaldi: Id use Tardis to travel to David Bowie Ziggy Stardust concertldquoWe canrsquot thank Keith and the lsquocauseplayersrsquo enough for their support. We simply couldnrsquot do the work we do without them and the rest of our passionate and committed supporters who are helping us on our mission of reaching every child in Scotland with a le-shortening condition.All profits raised by Capital Sci-Fi Con are donated to CHAS - the only charity in Scotland that provides hospice services for babies, children and young people with le-shortening conditions.The national charity offers palliative care and respite for the whole family via its two hospices, Rachel House in Kinross andRobin House in Balloch. Its CHAS atHome service supports families in their own homes across the whole of Scotland and has teams workingin communities and hospitals acrossthe country.

Connelly has worked in traffic control since  so theres not much he hasnt seen. The Beast from the East brought the worst weather conditions hes encountered during his many years of service. The team is both proactive and reactive in its mission to keep Scotland’s roads moving – planning for issues it can see coming and responding quickly to those that it can’t.Partnerships play an essential role in the day-to-day operations here.For example, we’re sitting in the resilience room where Transport Scotland, the Scottish Government agency which oversees our transport industry, meets during major crises, such as the Beast from the East.It is here, too, where action plans are drawn up to cope with major events on the annual calendar or roadworks on vital routes.A Police Scotland officer is based in the centre at peak times, along with Traffic Scotland’s media officers who Tweet updates throughout the day and INRIX, a radio team which transmits travel updates, both on the website and to most of our radio stations.From September to April, a MET office employee is also based in the centre.But Traffic Scotland has many more partners behind the scenes too.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.fetoday webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"It looks likely that the council will raise the areas Council Tax rates by three per cent"  Counterfeit cash alert after incidents reported in Fe viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "FFPL | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "FFPL | Article Teaser"Stein explained: “We work closely with event organisers to ensure people get to the Open or Royal Highland Show with as little disruption as possible, particularly when two major events are on at the same time.“We also work with the road operating companies, Freight Haulage Association and public transport providers, such as Abellio Scotrail. We co-ordinate road and rail works to minimise the impact for commuters and the Scottish economy.”With all of the country’s roadside SOS calls also being answered at the centre, there are few down times.It’s a round-the-clock job and often a tough one, with operators witnessing incidents that take a toll.Even Stein, despite his many years in the job, isn’t immune.He explained: “Operators can take a call from someone saying they’re going to jump off the Erskine Bridge, pan the camera round and see them jumping. That can really stay with someone.“One that sticks in my mind was an accident at Charing Cross in Glasgow.“The car was a mess and as we panned the camera round we saw a child’s car seat, empty, on the road.“The room fell quiet but nothing was said. Later on, the police told us there were no fatalities and no children had been hurt – the sense of relief here was amazing.”Staff have access to counselling, should they need it as a result of anything they’ve witnessed.But you get the sense of a camaraderie among the team too which undoubtedly helps get them through the tough days.Last February and March, the Beast from the East proved a real challenge – some operators didn’t make it home for days, while others couldn’t make it in.Stein was at the helm through it all, steering the ship through the worst road conditions witnessed in Scotland in a generation.He said: “It was pretty bad in  but the Beast from the East is the worst weather I’ve ever experienced.“Usually, we can marshall maintenance teams and gritters from one part of the country to help in other areas hit by severe weather. That just wasn’t possible. “I was camped out here for five days, as was Humza Yousaf, the then transport minister. The operators couldn’t get home either so they just got on with the job, like they always do.“It was the first red weather warning in Scotland – everyone learned from it.”A Hilltip Icestriker from Finland is now being trialled on the M to ensure recovery teams can access incidents and an electric powered spreader has been deployed on the M.As for daily operations, the public also has an important role to play.“We have just over  CCTV cameras on km of roads,” said Stein. “It’s not a lot to cover such a large area.“So the public are often our eyes and ears, alerting us to breakdowns so we can send out a recovery team.“We get a lot of thank you letters as a result.”Those worried about big brother watching need not fear either.Stein added: “We don’t record number plates or incidents, unless the police ask us to.“So while we get a lot of requests, we can’t help solicitors looking for accident recordings – we don’t have them.”Crossing over the Forth is now far more reliableTraffic Scotland’s National Control Centre was opened on April , , by then depute first minister Nicola Sturgeon. Also used as a contact and education centre for pupils to find out more about the £. billion Queensferry Crossing, thousands of children visited to get a bird’s eye view as the project unfolded. At . miles , it is the longest bridge of its type in the world and also the tallest, towering mhigh. But has it eased congestion for those travelling along the east coast artery between Fe and Edinburgh According to Traffic Scotland statistics, the crossing is very much doing the job it was intended for.Since September , there have been  occasions when the Forth Road Bridge would have been closed to high-sided vehicles due to high winds.Wind shielding on the new crossing enabled it to remain open, affording far more reliability for commuters and hauliers who regularly use it.The hard shoulder on the new bridge also means there are no longer lane closuresvehicles breakdown along its span.Stein said: “The crossing’s improved reliability is delivering benefits not only for commuters but for businesses and the wider Scottish economy too.”

title: crossing borders with your dog after brexit
story: A. The answer to this all depends on whether we leave the EU with or without a deal and when you want to travel.Pet passports wont be valid with a no deal BrexitAt the minute, you are supposed to have a pet passport for your dogtheyrsquore travelling from the UK to the EU and vice versa, although it is my understanding that there are no checks on pets crossing the Republic or Ireland and Northern Ireland border at the minute. Pet passports list the dferent treatments your pet has had and ensures they are microchipped and up to date with their rabies vaccine.Read more: JD Wetherspoon favours more UK products as Brexit moves closerThe passport means your pooch wont have to go into quarantine on arrival.If the UK leaves without a deal, then the rules will change and pet passports issued in the UK would no longer be valid.In this case, pet owners would need to get a health certicate - and the bad news is, this will take at least four months. Your dog will need a rabies vaccine with blood samplestaken  days after the jab. You will then have to wait three months after the samples come back clear to get the health certicate.The best thing to do is contact your vet for the latest advice four months before you hope to travel. data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.carricktoday webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"CE marking after Brexit"  CE marking after Brexit viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "CARR | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "CARR | Article Teaser"

title: driving voucher win for inverurie pupil
story: An Inverurie Academy pupil will soon be ready to take on the roads safely thanks to a prize from the British Transport Police.On Friday, November  last year British Transport Police officer Derek Jackson attended the school to give a Level Crossing presentation to th and th year pupils.The presentation aimed to highlight and promote safe driving standards to new and learning drivers whilst using a level crossing.After the presentation Derek handed out a quiz relating to driving standards and legislation with a top prize on offer.S pupil Shaun McCabe won and received a £ Red Driving School voucher.The prize was kindly sponsored by Network Rail.Derek presented Shaun with his prize on Wednesday, February , alongside Level Crossing Manager Michael Burnett and Lauren McCreedy, Mobile Operations Manager of Network Rail.Speaking to the Herald Shaun said he was “chuffed” to win the prize, and said he would put it towards Pass Plus, a training course that helps new drivers to improve their skills and drive more safely.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Police Scotland"  Man suffers serious injuries following crash viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: virtual subsea work for meldrum pupils
story: Meldrum Academy pupils have taken part in OPITO#s Energise Your Futureevent.The academy was one of eight north east schools to have taken part in the initiative that was held during the final day of Subsea Expo at the Aberdeen Exhibition and Conference Centre on Thursday, February .EYF is managed by OPITO, the global, not-for-profit, skills body for the energy industry.The event aims to inspire and encourage more young people in the UK to consider the industry as a career choice by providing a chance to get up close with key companies and people who can help explain their businesses as well as roles and routes into the sector.This year,  companies were involved in the Subsea Expo programme.Marine engineering firm EC-OG offered pupils the chance to use its latest virtual reality technology which will transport them subsea to inspect its subsea power hub and battery equipment.John McDonald, OPITO CEO, said: “As more and more oil and gas companies embrace new techniques such as virtual reality and articial intelligence, it is important that young people see and hear first-hand what the future of the industry looks like and the vast and exciting opportunities these developments present to them.”Attracting young talent remains a key focus for the sector.The recent OPITO UKCS Workforce Dynamics Review showed thatthe sector achieves its ambitions set out in Vision ,, people will need to be recruited over the next two decades.Around , of those are expected to be in roles that don’t yet exist.Mr McDonald added: “We are currently developing a new UKCS Skills Strategy to support the skills that will be required by both new and existing personnel operating in the North Sea into the next decade.“It is important we provide opportunities through initiatives like EYF to help young people discover that this is a sector with a future worth considering that also has the learning infrastructure in place to help develop their career and unlock their potential.”The pupils taking part were all aged between  to . The other schools at the event were Aberdeen Grammar, the International School Aberdeen, Oldmachar Academy, Albyn School, Mintlaw Academy, Robert Gordon’s College and Peterhead Academy.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Jemima Adeoye, Director of Education and Childrens Services Laurence Findlay, Elizabeth Lyall, Cooper Masson, Cllr Gillian Owen, Cllr Jim Gford, Provost Bill Howatson, Chief Executive Jim Savege, Tami Fadeyi, Ruaridh Cumming and Head Teacher Pamela Farquhar with pupils outside the new Kinellar School"  Community celebrates official opening of Kinellar School viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: masterchef stars for taste of grampian
story: Organisers of the annual Taste of Grampian event at Thainstone have announced this year#s celebrity chefs.At a special launch event Taste of Grampian chairman, John Gregor, revealed that MasterChef star John Torode will headline the th anniversary event on Saturday, June .Chef John said: “I’ve heard the produce in the north-east is some of the best to come out of Scotland.“I’m looking forward to finding some new food and drink producers and using their ingredients in my dishes on the day.”Joining John on the day will be reality TV star Spencer Matthews, who was a surprise finalist in Celebrity MasterChef last year.He will be demonstrating on the day as well as joining John for the main highlight of Taste of Grampian – a joint demonstration.Completing the MasterChef line-up for this year will be Scotland’s national chef, Gary Maclean who was crowned the winner of The Professionals title in .Gary will be demonstrating with Scotch Beef at this year’s eventand supported by Quality Meat Scotlandwho will be the main title sponsor.Also joining the celebrity line-up will be Helen Vass, who was part of the winning team of BBC’s Bake Off Crème de la Crème in . The award-winning pastry chef will be showcasing her baking skills at several demonstrations throughout the day.Commenting at the launch of Taste of Grampian Mr Gregor said: “This is an unmissable event in the Aberdeenshire calendar.“Whether you are a complete foodie or something of a novice chef, it’s a great way of showcasing an eclectic mix of new and established food and drink producers in the area.“We’re delighted to confirm a stellar celebrity line-up with John Torode, Spencer Matthews, Gary Maclean and Helen Vass and we look forward to celebrating our th anniversary in style.”data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.hawick-news webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Aberdeenshire East MSP Gillian Martin"  Constituents urged to get blood pressure checks viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Early bird tickets for Taste of Grampian  are available to purchase online now at www.eventbrite.

title: pick of the pops at annual clan fundraiser
story: A north-east charity has announced plans for a unique music-themed lunch event, to raise funds for its cancer support services.The CLAN Jukebox Lunch is the first of its kind, where, after enjoying a welcome glass of fizz, guests will be asked to choose their favourite tunes, which will be played throughout the afternoon.The  CLAN Jukebox Lunch will take place on Friday, May  at the Marclfe Hotel and Spa.In , over  men and women attended the annual event, which raised £, for CLAN’s cancer support services.During the afternoon in May, there will be a raffle and auction, live entertainment and a two-course lunch provided by the hotel’s renowned chefs. Guests will also be treated to a unique shopping experience, where local crafts people will showcase artworks, gts and clothing items.The popular fundraising lunch, which is sponsored by BP, promises to be a fantastic afternoon of music, shopping, entertainment and friendship.Steph McCann, CLAN Cancer Support’s Fundraising Team Manager, said: “The CLAN Lunch is one of CLAN’s most popular annual events, and we are excited to be adding a new theme this year where guests can request their favourite songs.“The Marclfe Hotel and Spa is an invaluable supporter of CLAN, and this event, with an even wider range of shopping stalls and entertainment, looks set to be the best yet.“CLAN is enormously grateful to our sponsor, BP, which enables us to ensure that every penny raised during the event will come directly to CLAN, helping to support anyone affected by a cancer diagnosis in the heart of communities throughout north-east Scotland, Moray, Orkney and Shetland."The CLAN lunch is always very popular, so we would encourage people to book their place now to avoid missing out.”Tickets for the CLAN Lunch, which will run from am to pm, are priced at £ each and are available inidually or as tables of , and can be purchased by visiting www.clanhouse.org or via the charity’s fundraising team by calling   or email fundraising@clanhouse.org.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.buchanobserver webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Unison wants talks with the council over the threat to jobs"  Unison seeks talks over council job cuts viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "BUCH | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "BUCH | Article Teaser"

title: santa paws donation for canine charity
story: An Aberdeenshire charity is celebrating after receiving a donation of over #,.Give A Greyhound A Homewas presented with a cheque for £, following kind donations from Inverurie Pets at Home customers.Before Christmas the charity took part in the Santa Paws Appeal at the store.Each p raised contributed towards a Christmas dinner for a homeless animal.Charity volunteer Steph Gravell said: “The team at Pets at Home were amazing, and volunteers from GAGAH attended with dogs every Saturday in December to help increase the total amount raised.“We would love to say a huge public thank you to Matt, Richard and the team, as well as raising more awareness for our Greyhounds currently in need of homes.”GAGAH is a local non profit organisation run solely by volunteers who foster and re-home ex-racing Greyhounds and ex-working Lurchers throughout Scotland.All rescued animals are introduced into a home environment, neutered, receive any additional veterinary treatment as required, before being matched to a suitable forever home.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.buchanobserver webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Heart of the action...the  inch television screens in the control centre aremonitored  hours a day,  days a year. title: the top six questions people are asking google about brexit
story: Heres the answers to your questions:What is the new Brexit Party, which has been supported by Nigel Farage What is the new Brexit Party and how do I join The Brexit Party was launched with the support of ex-UKIP leader Nigel Farage in January and recognised as an official party at the beginning of February . It is a pro-Brexit party. Farage has said he will stand as an MEP under the partythe UK does not leave the EU orArticle  is extended. An official website is coming soon, and you should be able to sign up then, but in the meantime you can search for Brexit Party UK on Facebook.Will my passport be valid after Brexit Theres no need to do anything until your current passport is ready for renewal. British passports will change after we leave the EU, with blue and gold passports making afrom October , but youll still be able to travel on your old burgundy passport until it runs out. If theres a no deal Brexit, youll need to have at least six months left on your passport to travel to an EU country. If you renewed your passport before it expired, then any extra months wont count either - your passport should not be any older than nine years and six months when you travel. What is ERG This stands for the European Research Group, which is a group of pro-Brexit Conservative MPs chaired by Jacob-Res Mogg. It is lobbying on issues surrounding Brexit. The group was in the news as it is expected to rebel against todays House of Commons motion which asks MPs to reiterate its support for renegotiating the controversial Irish backstop.Read more: Will UK workers lose their rights and entitlements after Brexit Will EHIC still be valid At the minute,we fall sick or get injured while visiting the EU, then we can access the same free or discounted medical care that is available to residents of that country. The European Health Insurance Cardproves your eligibility. Regardless of the deal reached, the government will need to renegotiate the reciprocal healthcare arrangements. At the minute, a bill called HealthcareBill is being passed through Parliament to help reach such an arrangement. It is important as the scheme provides healthcare for an estimated , UK expats living in the EU as well as  million UK residents who travel abroad to EEA countries each year Until a new initiative is in place, you should check what the agreement is with the country youre visiting as EHIC may not be valid. Make sure you have travel insurance too .Will I need a visa for my holiday Not for short-term stays for holidays or business purposes. This is providing the UK offers the same deal for EU citizens who want to visit us. We will, however, have to to pay a fee to visit Europe after Brexit. From , youll need to fill in a ETIAS application form so other countries can check youre not a security threat. This is similar to the US ESTA scheme. title: uryside park secures european funding
story: The development of Inverurie#s Ury Riverside Park has taken a major step forward with a funding award of over #,.A total of £, was awarded from the LEADER fund, set up to support rural development, and will be used to undertake a wide range of planting within the site.The contract for the planting has been awarded to Aberdeenshire-based CR Contracting North Ltd, which has already done work around the park.Company Director Chris Rogerson said: “We’re really pleased to have been awarded this contract for planting – we also recently constructed the path network, so we are happy to continue with the further development of the park.“Our plan is to complete the path network, then to plant the wet woodland, grassland and wetland meadow areas.“Assuming the weather is favourable we aim to complete the works by winter next year.”The development of the park is managed by a local charity, Ury Riverside Park SCIO.Trustee of the Ury Riverside Park charitable organisation, Claire Maycock, said: “It’s great to see the area develop.“We recently held a volunteer day and planted , trees, so further planting will really enhance the site and make it feel more like a park.”Chair of the Garioch Area Committee, Fergus Hood, added: “This is great news for the Inverurie area, the development of the park is really exciting, and the award of this most recent funding will help move forward with the plans.”European funding programme LEADER allocates cash grants to projects which contribute to key themes identied in Local Development Strategies, such as connectivity, business competitiveness, the environment and people and place.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! title: volunteer plea for community companions
story: Royal Voluntary Service is looking for volunteers to become Community Companions, a scheme which offers practical support to older people in Inverurie.Tracey Peden, Community Development Operations Manager at Royal Voluntary Service said: “We are initially looking for one or two volunteer coordinators and volunteers to support the scheme in Inverurie, but there is scope to develop the Community Companions service across Aberdeenshire.“Our volunteers find they get as much out of volunteering as they put in it’s incredibly rewarding for them and they make a real dference to the lives of the people they support.“Those who sign up can choose to dedicate as much or as little time to volunteering as they like and full training will be given.”Community Companions volunteers offer the practical help that can make all the dference to older people and help them retain their independence– from assisted shopping and activity programmes, to enabling them to get out and about with community transport. Volunteers also provide company and companionship, while making sure the older person is safe and well.Royal Voluntary Service is one of Britain’s largest volunteering charities with over , volunteers supporting thousands of people each month in hospitals, at home and in the community.To find out more about becoming volunteer call   or email tracey.hann@royalvoluntaryservice.org.uk.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.milngavieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Level Crossing Manager Michael Burnett, Shaun McCabe, PC Derek Jackson and Lauren McCreedy of Network Rail"  Driving voucher win for Inverurie pupil viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: Caithness to get firts vegan BB
story: A BED and breakfast with a dference is to be launched in Caithness next month.Barbara and Peter Gray, who live in Berriedale, will be opening what is thought to be the first vegan BB in the far north and the venture is already attracting interest online from people throughout the UK.The couple moved to Caithness in September after purchasing a property in the village.They come from Derbyshire but spent some time in Lincolnshire before moving to Golspie and then to Caithness.They say they both like the Highlands and wanted to set up a vegan bed and breakfast here.Barbara explained: ldquoWe saw the property at The Braes in Berriedale was up for sale last summer, put in an offer and it was accepted.ldquoAt present, we have a king size double en suite room but would hope to expand and have two to three rooms later.ldquoAs far as I know we are the only vegan BB in Caithness. I think the nearest one to us may be in Aviemore.ldquoFor a long time we have wanted to provide luxury accommodation and cooking for vegans but we will also show people how to cook vegan meals and may do workshops on an ad hoc basis as well as hosting special s for events such as Valentines Day and Burns Nights.ldquoWe will be open for business in March but are already getting interest online from people in the UK and hope eventually to generate interest in Europe and the USA.Asked what would happensomeone who is not a vegan wanted to stay at the BB, she replied: ldquoThey would have to take vegan food as we do not have animal products on the premises.ldquoWe live a vegan lestyle and would prefer vegans to stay here but they donrsquot have to be vegans.Her husband Peter helps run the business but is also a writer.He has been writing for many years but in  started work on a series of crime fiction books whose main character is Detective Inspector James Avalon. The police officer is based in Inverness but travels throughout the Highlands.Monday  Feb  : AM

title: Call goes out for transport review in Thurso
story: A COMPREHENSIVE transport review is required in Thurso, according to a local Highland councillor.Karl Rosie made the plea this week after the issue of speeding and parking was raised at a meeting of the local community council.Chairman Mike Potts noted that a  mph restriction is planned for large sections of Wick and wondered what was happening in Thurso. He said some areas of the town, such as Shore Street and Upper Ormlie, had been designated as one-way streets some time ago but this had not been implemented. "That needs to be corrected," he said at Tuesday nights meeting.Mr Potts and other community councillors felt something had to be done to address the issue of speeding and one suggestion was for more sleeping policemen to be installed in problem areas of Thurso.Councillor Rosie, who represents Thurso and Northwest Caithness on Highland Council, said what is needed is a transport review which can take a comprehensive look at the issue. "We need a strategic look at the whole thing ndash something which covers transport management and pedestrians," he said.However, community councillor and former police officer Bert MacLeod urged caution. He said: "You need to be careful you dont go overboard with this  mph limit. Modern cars can stop quicker than vehicles did in the past. We need to be sensible."Mr Potts claimed "some of the driving in Thurso is abysmal".Mr MacLeod replied: "Why should you and I be affected because someone drives like an idiot "He also pointed out there are problems with installing sleeping policemen on roads. New laws have been introduced as cars have been damaged by them, he said."It is not just a case of putting them down," stated Mr MacLeod. He argued that enforcement is the key to tackling the problem."If you had a traffic warden in each town again that would help," he added.Community councillor Colin Johnston said something should be done to address the issue of traffic and parking in the town.Struan Mackie, another Thurso and Northwest Caithness Highland councillor, stressed that it takes time to process traffic orders and pointed out that the mph plan for Wick began over two years ago.He also pointed out that the county is going to get traffic enforcement officers which should help deal with some of the parking issues.Mr MacLeod commented: "You have got to watch you do not overdo these things."But Mr Potts said: "Parking has been an issue for a long time. It is up to us to keep fighting. There is parking available in the town so the problem can be overcome. That should be our war cry all the time."Monday  Feb  : AM

title: Flexibility plea on new GP deal
story: THE problems facing GPs in Caithness have been outlined to Scotlandrsquos health secretary Jeane Freeman by two north MSPs.Rhoda Grant and David Stewart.Labour representatives for the Highlands and Islands, met with Ms Freeman to express their concern about the new GP contract and the impact it could have on rural and remote areas.They were accompanied by Phil Wilson, a professor of primary care and rural health at the University of Aberdeen and a GP in Inverness.Also present was a Dingwall GP Miles Mack.Mrs Grant asked Ms Freeman for the face-to-face meeting at the Scottish Parliament and highlighted issues which GPs across the Highlands and Islands have raised with her and Mr Stewart.The doctors told the minister that five of the  permanent GPs in Caithness are likely to retire in the next five years.Ms Freeman heard that since  almost half of all permanent GP posts in the county have been vacant and partially replaced with short-term locum provision.Three practices have ceased to be independent contractors and have been taken over by NHS Highland.Concerns were also raised about the capacity for undergraduate teaching and the effect on retention and recruitment of GPs in remote areas.Doctors have told the MSPs that the new contract fails to recognise the workload in rural areas where surgeries deal with a far greater range of medical problems, including emergencies that would be dealt with in hospitals in urban areas.Mrs Grant said: ldquoThe main concern is that whatrsquos on the table with the new contract is an urban model and this just doesnrsquot suit remote and rural areas.ldquoGPs are worried it will cause poor continuity of care for patients and that procedures currently performed at surgeries are being centralised ndash for instance for blood tests or vaccinations.ldquoThis will inevitably inconvenience patients and worsen health outcomes by raising barriers to care.ldquoThe contract states that other healthcare professionals will be employed to deal with these extra tasks ndash but with rural GP posts remaining unfilled, and shortages of nurses in many areas, how can we expect to find these extra people in our out-of-the-way places ldquoThere must be flexibility for GPs to retain the old system of care.The new contractrsquos funding formula has been based on the number of appointmentsand does not take account of the issues faced by rural areas such as patient and doctor travel.ldquoGPs in our region cannot wait for another three years to see some movement on this and Irsquom hopeful that the health secretary will find a suitable way forward.At the meeting Ms Freeman said she had ldquogenuinely taken the issues seriously and discussion would continue with colleagues. Mrs Grant was promised an update in two months.Monday  Feb  : AM

title: Plans to tackle Wick town centre parking hailed as very good news
story: Local Highland councillor Andrew Sinclair said he welcomed the proposals outlined in a traffic order as they give the local authority greater powers to deal with what has been a contentious issue for many years.Many other areas of Wick would also be subject to restrictions.Councillor Sinclair, who represents the Wick and East Caithness ward, said: "I think this is very good news for the town. We have been calling for more parking enforcement in Wick for a while now."High Street and Bridge Street are far too regularly packed with cars parked where they shouldnt be. Its an issue that has been raised time and time again by both drivers and pedestrians. Some people think they are above the rules and for too long theyve got away with it."He added: "Under the current proposals Bridge Street and much of High Street will essentially become double yellows, meaning no parking at any time. This should also help stop the constant issue of people selfishly parking in areas like the Market Square."The parking bays there are intended only for those who are disabled badge holders but these rules are often ignored by people who just canrsquot be bothered walking."Councillor Sinclair said the order would give council officers the power to enforce parking restrictions once they receive the required training but, initially, existing enforcement staff would carry out the work."We should expect a much more regular presence than under the old system," he said. "The discussions Irsquove had with the officer responsible for parking have been extremely encouraging."Having an enforcement officer in the town for regular and random visits is a great start butthe situation doesnrsquot improve we will still be pushing to get someone in this post locally to clamp down on rogue drivers."He explained that in Inverness several council employees have been trained to undertake parking enforcement duties as well as their day-to-day jobs. "There is no reason why the same couldnrsquot be done up here. If these orders get the go-ahead, and I am confident they will, then I hope we will begin to see a dference in peoples behaviour."The Caithness civic leader, Councillor Willie Mackay, also backed the plan. "It is a fantastic idea but it is the enforcement that is the key to the success of this," he said. "If we can get enough staff trained up to act as traffic wardens ndash and I am pretty sure we can ndash then their presence will deter bad parking."Parking in the centre of Wick has been a contentious problem for some time and has often been raised by the local community council and others. If this is approved, it will make a massive dference to the town centre, although there will always be some motorists who will take a chance and park there."However, Councillor Mackay has misgivings about the extent of the restrictions planned for other parts of Wick.Monday  Feb  : AM

title: Prince Harry set to attend Mey games
story: THE Mey Highland Games is going to ldquoput Caithness in the global spotlight, according to its organiser Captain Richard Otley, after Prince Harry announced he would attend the event this year.Rumours were re last year that Harry and his we Meghan would attend the special event which included para-athletes for the first time but when the royal retinue appeared at pm there was no sign of the couple.Capt Otley believes that the information released over the weekend to the media about Prince Harryrsquos attendance may have come from Buckingham Palace itself. He was unable to confirmMeghan would attend along with her husband, but said it would be ldquotruly fantastic for Caithness and help put it on the mapthe royal couple turned up.The Duke and Duchess of Sussex will welcome their first child this spring.Monday  Feb  : AM

title: This weeks Caithness Courier
story: Due to circumstances beyond our control, this weekrsquos edition of the Caithness Courier wonrsquot be in the shops until Thursday morning. We apologise for any inconvenience but this was due to a combination of problems with our contract printers and distribution partners.Monday  Feb  : AM

title: Trailblazers on right path
story: MEMBERS of Wick Paths Group joined forces with Friends of the John OGroats Trail to improve a path used by walkers visiting the Castle of Old Wick.They got stuck in to the task of upgrading the narrow, muddy and uneven section from the old rle range to the field at the Grey Bools. The path had been scraped out in advance by Nordwall Landscaping to a width of . metres and some  tonnes of quarry gravel had been purchased and delivered to site.On the work day  volunteers turned out to help and they were grateful for the heavy machinery loaned by Hugh Simpson , M M Miller and Graham Begg. The gravel was laid in just under three hours and has resulted in a much-improved route.Wick Paths Group chairman Allan Tait said: "We are very grateful to all the volunteers who turned out to help, to the landowners for giving permission and to the local businesses for lending their equipment. The path is very popular with local people for walking and running as well as the increasing use by those walking the John OGroats Trail."This section of path is now immensely better than it was and I hope it will encourage many more people to come out and walk the route."Jay Wilson, chairman of the John OGroats Trail group, said: "Im very pleased to see a great turnout of Wick volunteers to build a path for the town that also forms part of the overall John OGroats Trail."Monday  Feb  : AM

title: We have saved part of our identity
story: THE Dunnet and Canisbay area would have lost part of its identityits community council had been scrapped due to boundary changes, vice-chairman Bill Mowat has said.He welcomed last weeks change of heart by Highland Council and said he was very pleased the body had been saved.Under the proposals, Dunnet and Canisbay would have been linked with Castletown and Bower community councils.Mr Mowat said the area would have lost part of its identitythe plan, which would also have seen the demise of Sinclairs Bay Community Council, went ahead.Details were reported in the John OGroat Journal last Friday."Community councils are of real value when you have got a single-tier council and you dont have a councillor representing the area," Mr Mowat said. "We are very pleased with the outcome which is a small victory for localism."We are relieved we are to continue. There was an indicationthis proposal was forced through most members would not have bothered to continue attending meetings."Mr Mowat pointed out that Canisbay and Dunnet are historic settlements based on a crofting background and said that would have been lost under the plan. "We are delighted we are to continue. This decision keeps our identity in this north-east corner which goes back to the end of the th century," he said.He stressed there had been strong opposition to the plan and added: "It is hardly our fault , as is being claimed, some neighbouring community councils may not be ing as well as some observers might desire. Dunnet and Canisbay should not be punished for this."Mr Mowat explained that Highland councillor Andrew Sinclairhad made the case for retention as he is the current local authority representative on Dunnet and Canisbay Community Council. Councillor Sinclair made a similar plea to retain Sinclairs Bay Community Council whose future was also threatened. Part of its area would have been linked with Wick.Monday  Feb  : AM

title: Wick Francis Street Club placed in liquidation
story: WICKS Francis Street Club has been placed in liquidation, it was confirmed on Thursday.According to provisional liquidator Iain Fraser, a partner with FRP Advisory, the decision was made following a decline in membership, rising costs and unsustainable cash-flow problems. The club ndash founded in the s as a British Legion ndash has now closed and six staff have been made redundant.Mr Fraser said: "The Francis Street Club has been a landmark social, entertainment and sports venue in Caithness for nearly  years. Sadly, the club has been suffering severe financial problems and liquidation was the only option available to the committee."We are working closely with the relevant agencies, including the Redundancy Payments Office, to ensure the staff receive as much support as possible. We are now offering the assets of the business for sale, including the building, fixtures and fittings, and would urge interested parties to contact our Aberdeen office as soon as possible on   ."The Francis Street Club started was a long-established social, entertainment and sporting venue which attracted some well-known names through its doors, including former world snooker champion Stephen Hendry who staged an exhibition match there.It served as a social club and ran both football and darts teams, both well supported by members.It also operated as an entertainment venue, with music and entertainment acts from across the country putting in appearances to local acclaim.The premises closed last month. At the time, a statement issued by the club said: "It was decided by the committee to close the Francis Street Club and Institute Limited at midnight on Wednesday, January , ."A note subsequently posted on the door read: "We have ceased trading from immediate effect at these premises the Francis Street Club Wick. All other details will follow in due course."Monday  Feb  : AM

title: Wicks Francis Street Club closes
story: Wick institution the Francis Street Club has been forced to close due to financial dficulties. ldquoIt was decided by the committee to close the Francis Street Club and Institute Limited at midnight on Wednesday, January , , the spokesperson, who did not wish to be named, said.A note subsequently posted on its door read: ldquoWe have ceased trading from immediate effect at these premises the Francis Street Club Wick. All other details will follow in due course.The building first opened as a British Legion in the s, and remained a popular focal point for the community.It served as a social club and ran football and darts teams ndash both well-supported by members.It also operated as an entertainment venue, with music and entertainment acts from across the country putting in appearances to local acclaim.One famous occasion took place in  when Councillor Willie Mackay was able to persuade top darts players Jocky Wilson and Eric Bristow to play an exhibition match ndash a fixture Scotsman Wilson won.However, it is expected that such nights will now become a thing of the past.It is not known what the future of the building holds, orany parties are considering taking the club over.The spokesperson stressed the committee was ldquovery sad the club had to close.Monday  Feb  : AM

title: blocking the bus in the hope
story: Police Scotland and Orkney Islands Council are asking drivers to ‘think bus’ when leaving vehicles in St Margaret’s Hope.The X service is frequently prevented from travelling through the village when stationary cars and vans block the narrow entrance to the Back Road from Pier Road and Cromarty Square.“If the bus can’t travel along the Back Road it has to take the new road instead and passengers waiting in the village miss their bus,” said East Mainland, South Ronaldsay and Burray councillor, Steve Sankey.“It’s a growing problem and something bus users and the local community council have raised with me. People expect a reliable service and I can understand their frustration. We’re joining with the Police in asking drivers not to block the way into the Back Road and find somewhere  to park that doesn’t affect the bus.”Chief Inspector Matt Webb, Police Scotland Area Commander for Orkney, said: “We will take actionvehicles are left in ways which restrict the passage of the local bus service.“We would rather not do thatpossible # and I would encourage drivers to be considerate and play their part in making sure buses can move freely through the narrow streets of the village.”If you have any comments or feedback on bus services, please contact the Transportation Team at the Council at transport@orkney.gov.uk or  . title: council issues kirkyards apology
story: Orkney Islands Council has made an official apology following public concern about the way the county#s kirkyards are being managed.Distraught families and dismayed public officials have spoken out in recent weeks, after a scheme to improve the safety of cemeteries triggered reports that headstones were being laid flat without relatives being notied.Last week, a council insider told The Orcadian that — in failing to contact families — the council was disregarding government guidelines on cemetery maintenance.“It says it’s good practice to inform the families and give them an opportunity to repair the memorial, and that’s just not being done at all,” the inside source said.The Orcadian also heard from Stewart Spence, whose father#s headstone had been laid down in the Sandwick kirkyard with no notication from the council. This was despite the fact that the name and address of the person they needed to contact — his mother Edna — was engraved on the memorial.#Vandals couldn#t have done a better job,# he said.Following this wave of public concern, OIC convener Harvey Johnston and chief executive Alistair Buchan have now released a statement apologising for the concern and upset that this project has caused.#Following a tragic accident involving a young child at a Glasgow cemetery, the Scottish Government asked councils to carry out detailed inspections in the interests of public safety,# they said.#We therefore engaged in the kirkyard safety programme for all the right reasons, but recognise that the process we have followed needs to be improved. It was never envisaged that the resulting work would leave kirkyards in the condition they are in. We are sorry about the concern and upset this has led to.#As a caring organisation, responsive to public concern, we will restore kirkyards to the condition people would expect. We will also consider how best to contact and discuss the remedial work required with those concerned. People’s safety is an important concern for us and we will continue to carry out headstone inspections. As at Warebeth , we will use blue pegs to mark stones identied as being unsafe and highlight these to local community representatives.#These stones will not be touched until we publicise the inspection results and give relatives the time they need to discuss with us any work they might wish to carry out themselves.#The statement also confirmed that further updates from the council will be provided further updates over the weeks ahead.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: interactive hie roadshow comes to orkney
story: newsInteractive HIE roadshow comes to OrkneyFebruary ,  at : pm vw, px"  Starting here in Orkney this week, Highlands and Islands Enterprise is hitting the road to teach people how to outsmart online criminals and spot cyber threats.The free Cyber Sense on Tour workshops will visit businesses and communities throughout the Highlands and Islands using fun, interactive games to allow participants to get under the skin of hackers and learn the tricks of the trade.The tour starts in Orkney with two events, the first at Orkney Library this Tuesday, February , and the second at the NorthLink ferry Hamnavoe at the Stromness terminal on Wednesday.The interactive experience is open to all and will use innovative technology to create an immersive ‘point of view’ exercise, were participants can take the role of an employee, a cyber security professional and even a hacker to learn the tricks of the trade.Concepts such as ‘phishing’ will be explained and audiences will be taught to spot scams, dissect spurious emails and prevent hackers taking over their online lives.Working in collaboration with the National Cyber Security Centreand supported by the Scottish Government, the Cyber Sense sessions will provide a memorable and engaging way to discover how everyday actions can help protect people and companies from these evolving cyber dangers.April Conroy, project manager at Highland and Islands Enterprise, said: “As the way we work and live becomes more integrated online, it can be easy to take for granted how much important information we upload to the internet. Whether it’s our personal information on social media or important financial details, it’s vital that we’re aware of how to keep our safe and secure from cyber criminals.”“By really getting under the skin of these hackers, our Cyber Sense workshops can point out how to understand how these iniduals work. Through the games we’ve designed, attendees will be able to competitively play roles on both sides of a cyber-crime. This offers a unique perspective that can show just what preventative measures can be taken to outsmart these online criminals.”To learn more about the Cyber Sense on Tour event and to book a free place, visit www.hellodigital.scot cyber-sense- copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: in the footsteps of dr john rae
story: Next month will see a group of intrepid adventurers undertake a -mile mission in the Canadian Arctic, retracing the footsteps of one of Orkney#s most renowned, yet also overlooked, sons — Dr John Rae.The Arctic Return expedition will see a four-man team set off from Naujaat — also known as Repulse Bay — in late March, aiming to retrace the footsteps made by the surgeon, explorer and surveyor in .It was on that expedition that the explorer finally discovered an open channel to the east of King William Island in the high arctic. Known today as Rae Strait, it was the missing link in what would become the first navigable Northwest Passage.He also reported back on the ill-fated Franklin expedition, reported evidence of cannibalism — findings which were effectively rejected by the then establishment, and which led to Rae#s achievements being almost completely ignored.The modern-day team, who hope to raise further awareness of these achievements, will be led by Scottish-born and Canada-based expedition leader David Reid, with Scotland also represented by Broxburn-based former Royal Marine Richard Smith.The team will also include two Canadians — adventure film-maker Gerry Tutte and adventurer Frank Wolf.Over  years later and supported with modern-day kit from outdoor specialists Tiso, the explorers are hard at work preparing for the physical and mental challenge of hauling kg sledges for nine hours daily and for up to  consecutive days.Their route will cover undulating, windswept tundra, river valleys and sea ice during what can be the coldest time of year.The Arctic expedition will finish once the four explorers have finally reached Gjoa Haven on King William Island.Mr Smith said: #The Arctic Return expedition will be extremely tough but ultimately our aim is to raise awareness fo the exploits of John Rae and to help restore his rightful place as one of the greatest Scottish explorers in history. It is also our hope that this awareness will inspire the public to support fundraising efforts by the John Rae Society, to restore Rae#s birthplace at the Hall of Clestrain in Oprhir.The team have said any addition funds raised are to be used to produce a documentary film and book about the le and exploits of Rae, the expedition and the history communities, culture and wildle of the Arctic.The public will be able to track the team#s progress at their official website and through social media.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co.
